text: These are the names of the sons of Israel (that is, Jacob) who came with him to Egypt with their families:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah;
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan and Naphtali; Gad and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was already in Egypt. The total number of Jacob’s descendants was 70.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Joseph, all his brothers, and that entire generation died.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the descendants of Israel had many children. They became so numerous and strong that the land was filled with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a new king, who knew nothing about Joseph, began to rule in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his people, “There are too many Israelites, and they are stronger than we are.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have to outsmart them, or they’ll increase in number. Then, if war breaks out, they will join our enemies, fight against us, and leave the country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Egyptians put slave drivers in charge of them in order to oppress them through forced labor. They built Pithom and Rameses as supply cities for Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the more the Israelites were oppressed, the more they increased in number and spread out. The Egyptians couldn’t stand them any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they forced the Israelites to work hard as slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made their lives bitter with back-breaking work in mortar and bricks and every kind of work in the fields. All the jobs the Egyptians gave them were brutally hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Egypt told the Hebrew midwives, whose names were Shiphrah and Puah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you help the Hebrew women in childbirth, look at the child when you deliver it. If it’s a boy, kill it, but if it’s a girl, let it live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the midwives feared God and didn’t obey the king of Egypt’s orders. They let the boys live.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Egypt called for the midwives. He asked them, “Why have you done this? Why have you let the boys live?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The midwives answered Pharaoh, “Hebrew women are not like Egyptian women. They are so healthy that they have their babies before a midwife arrives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God was good to the midwives. So the people increased in number and became very strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because the midwives feared God, he gave them families of their own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh commanded all his people to throw into the Nile every Hebrew boy that was born, but to let every girl live.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man from Levi’s family married a Levite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman became pregnant and had a son. She saw how beautiful he was and hid him for three months.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she couldn’t hide him any longer, she took a basket made of papyrus plants and coated it with tar and pitch. She put the baby in it and set it among the papyrus plants near the bank of the Nile River.
speaker: Narrator

text: The baby’s sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Pharaoh’s daughter came to the Nile to take a bath, her servants walked along the bank of the river. She saw the basket among the papyrus plants and sent her slave girl to get it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter opened the basket, looked at the baby, and saw it was a boy. He was crying, and she felt sorry for him. She said, “This is one of the Hebrew children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the baby’s sister asked Pharaoh’s daughter, “Should I go and get one of the Hebrew women to nurse the baby for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She answered, “Yes!” So the girl brought the baby’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pharaoh’s daughter said to the woman, “Take this child, nurse him for me, and I will pay you.”
She took the child and nursed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the child was old enough, she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. Pharaoh’s daughter named him Moses [Pulled Out] and said, “I pulled him out of the water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time Moses grew up. Then he went to see his own people and watched them suffering under forced labor. He saw a Hebrew, one of his own people, being beaten by an Egyptian.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked all around, and when he didn’t see anyone, he beat the Egyptian to death and hid the body in the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses went there the next day, he saw two Hebrew men fighting. He asked the one who started the fight, “Why are you beating another Hebrew?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man asked, “Who made you our ruler and judge? Are you going to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid and thought that everyone knew what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Pharaoh heard what Moses had done, he tried to have him killed. But Moses fled from Pharaoh and settled in the land of Midian.
One day, while Moses was sitting by a well,
speaker: Narrator

text: seven daughters of the priest of Midian came. They drew water and filled the troughs to water their father’s sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some shepherds came and chased them away. So Moses got up, came to their defense, and then watered their sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came back to their father Reuel, he asked them, “Why have you come home so early today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered, “An Egyptian rescued us from some shepherds. He even drew water for us and watered the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuel asked his daughters, “Where is he? Why did you leave the man there? Go, invite him to supper.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses decided to stay with the man. So Reuel gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave birth to a son. Moses named him Gershom [Foreigner], because he said, “I was a foreigner living in another country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After a long time passed, the king of Egypt died. The Israelites still groaned because they were slaves. So they cried out, and their cries for help went up to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard their groaning, and he remembered his promise  to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: God saw the Israelites being oppressed and was concerned about them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was taking care of the sheep of his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian. As he led the sheep to the far side of the desert, he came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Messenger of the Lord appeared to him there as flames of fire coming out of a bush. Moses looked, and although the bush was on fire, it was not burning up.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he thought, “Why isn’t this bush burning up? I must go over there and see this strange sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Lord saw that Moses had come over to see it, God called to him from the bush, “Moses, Moses!”
Moses answered, “Here I am!”
speaker: God

text: God said, “Don’t come any closer! Take off your sandals because this place where you are standing is holy ground.
speaker: God

text: I am the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.” Moses hid his face because he was afraid to look at God.
speaker: God

text: The Lord said, “I have seen the misery of my people in Egypt, and I have heard them crying out because of the slave drivers. I know how much they’re suffering.
speaker: God

text: I have come to rescue them from the power of the Egyptians and to bring them from that land to a good land with plenty of room for everyone. It is a land flowing with milk and honey where the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites live.
speaker: God

text: I have heard the cry of the people of Israel. I have seen how the Egyptians are oppressing them.
speaker: God

text: Now, go! I am sending you to Pharaoh so that you can bring my people Israel out of Egypt.”
speaker: God

text: But Moses said to God, “Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the people of Israel out of Egypt?”
speaker: God

text: God answered, “I will be with you. And this will be the proof that I sent you: When you bring the people out of Egypt, all of you will worship God on this mountain.”
speaker: God

text: Then Moses replied to God, “Suppose I go to the people of Israel and say to them, ‘The God of your ancestors has sent me to you,’ and they ask me, ‘What is his name?’ What should I tell them?”
speaker: God

text: God answered Moses, “I Am Who I Am. This is what you must say to the people of Israel: ‘I Am has sent me to you.’ ”
speaker: God

text: Again God said to Moses, “This is what you must say to the people of Israel: The Lord God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, has sent me to you. This is my name forever. This is my title throughout every generation.
speaker: God

text: “Go, assemble the leaders of Israel. Say to them, ‘The Lord God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, appeared to me. He said, “I have paid close attention to you and have seen what has been done to you in Egypt.
speaker: God

text: I promise I will take you away from your misery in Egypt to the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, a land flowing with milk and honey.” ’
speaker: God

text: “The leaders of Israel will listen to you. Then you and the leaders must go to the king of Egypt and say to him, ‘The Lord God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us travel three days into the desert to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God.’
speaker: God

text: I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, even if he is forced to.
speaker: God

text: So I will use my power to strike Egypt. After all the miracles that I will do there, he will let you go.
speaker: God

text: I will make the Egyptians kind to the people of Israel so that, when you leave, you will not leave empty-handed.
speaker: God

text: “Every Hebrew woman should ask her Egyptian neighbor and any woman living in her home for silver and gold jewelry and for clothes. Put them on your sons and daughters. This way you will strip Egypt of its wealth.”
speaker: God

text: “They will never believe me or listen to me!” Moses protested. “They will say, ‘The Lord didn’t appear to you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord asked him, “What’s that in your hand?”
He answered, “A shepherd’s staff.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said, “Throw it on the ground.”
When Moses threw it on the ground, it became a snake, and he ran away from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Reach out and grab the snake by its tail.” He reached out and grabbed it, and it turned back into a staff as he held it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord explained, “This is to convince the people that the Lord God of their ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, appeared to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Put your hand inside your shirt.” So Moses did this, and when he took his hand out, it had a skin disease. It looked as flaky as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now put your hand back inside your shirt,” the Lord said. Moses put it back, and when he took it out this time, it was healthy again like the rest of his body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “If they won’t believe you or pay attention to the first miraculous sign, they may believe the second.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they won’t believe these two miraculous signs or listen to you, take some water from the Nile River and pour it on the ground. The water you take from the Nile will turn into blood on the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “Please, Lord, I’m not a good speaker. I’ve never been a good speaker, and I’m not now, even though you’ve spoken to me. I speak slowly, and I become tongue-tied easily.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord asked him, “Who gave humans their mouths? Who makes humans unable to talk or hear? Who gives them sight or makes them blind? It is I, the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now go, and I will help you speak and will teach you what to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Please, Lord, send someone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord became angry with Moses and asked, “What about your brother Aaron the Levite? I know he can speak well. He’s already on his way to meet you, and he will be very glad to see you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will speak to him and tell him what to say. I will help both of you speak, and I will teach you both what to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron will speak to the people for you. He will be your spokesman, and you will be like God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take that shepherd’s staff with you, and use it to do the miraculous signs.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Moses went back to his father-in-law Jethro. Moses said to him, “Please let me go back to my own people in Egypt. I would like to see if they’re still alive.”
Jethro said to Moses, “You may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, the Lord had said to Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, because all the men who wanted to kill you are dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took his wife and sons, put them on a donkey, and started out for Egypt. He also brought with him the staff God had told him to take.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “When you get back to Egypt, see that you show Pharaoh all the amazing things that I have given you the power to do. But I will make him stubborn so that he will not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then tell Pharaoh, ‘This is what the Lord says: Israel is my firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: I told you to let my son go so that he may worship me. But you refused to let him go. So now I’m going to kill your firstborn son.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Along the way they stopped for the night. The Lord met Moses and tried to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zipporah took a flint knife, cut off her son’s foreskin, and touched Moses’ feet with it. She said, “You are a bridegroom of blood to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord let him alone. It was because of the circumcision that she said at that time, “You are a bridegroom of blood!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meanwhile, the Lord had told Aaron to meet Moses in the desert.
When Aaron met Moses at the mountain of God, he kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron everything the Lord had sent him to say and all the miraculous signs the Lord had commanded him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went to Egypt and assembled all the leaders of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron told them everything the Lord had said to Moses. He also did the miraculous signs for the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the people believed them. When they heard that the Lord was concerned about the people of Israel and that he had seen their misery, they knelt, bowing with their faces touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Let my people go into the desert to celebrate a festival in my honor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh asked, “Who is the Lord? Why should I obey him and let Israel go? I don’t know the Lord, and I won’t let Israel go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us travel three days into the desert to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God. If we don’t go, he may kill us with a plague or a war.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why are you distracting the people from their work? Get back to work!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh added, “Look how many people there are in the land! Do you want them to quit working?”
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Pharaoh gave these orders to the slave drivers and foremen:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t give the people any more straw to make bricks as you have been doing. Let them gather their own straw,
speaker: Narrator

text: but insist that they make the same number of bricks they were making before. Making fewer bricks will not be acceptable. They’re lazy! That’s why they’re crying, ‘Let us go offer sacrifices to our God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the work harder for these people so that they will be too busy to listen to lies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The slave drivers and foreman went out and said to them, “This is what Pharaoh says: I’m no longer giving you straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get your own straw wherever you can find it, but your work load will not be reduced one bit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people scattered all over Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slave drivers kept hurrying them. They said, “Finish the same amount of work each day, just as when you had straw.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s slave drivers had placed Israelite foremen in charge of the people. The slave drivers beat the foremen and said, “You didn’t finish all the bricks you were ordered to make yesterday or today. Why didn’t you make as many as you used to?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelite foremen complained to Pharaoh. They asked, “Why are you treating us this way?
speaker: Narrator

text: We’re given no straw, and yet we’re told to make bricks. We’re being beaten, but your men are at fault.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’re lazy! Just plain lazy!” Pharaoh answered. “That’s why you keep saying, ‘Let us go offer sacrifices to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now get back to work! You won’t be given any straw, but you must still make the same number of bricks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite foremen realized they were in trouble when they were told, “Don’t make fewer bricks each day than you’re supposed to.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they left Pharaoh, they found Moses and Aaron waiting for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said, “May the Lord see what you have done and judge you! You have made Pharaoh and his officials hate us. You have given them an excuse to kill us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went back to the Lord and asked, “Why have you brought this trouble on your people? Why did you send me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Ever since I went to Pharaoh to speak for you, he has treated your people cruelly, and you have done nothing at all to rescue your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh. I will show him my power, and he will let my people go. I will show him my power, and he will throw them out of his country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God spoke to Moses, “I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but I didn’t make myself known to them by my name, the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I even made a promise  to give them Canaan, the land where they lived as foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians hold in slavery, and I have remembered my promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘I am the Lord. I will bring you out from under the oppression of the Egyptians, and I will free you from slavery. I will rescue you with my powerful arm and with mighty acts of judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will make you my people, and I will be your God. You will know that I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from under the forced labor of the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you to the land I solemnly swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. I will give it to you as your own possession. I am the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses reported this to the Israelites. But they would not listen to him because they were so discouraged by their back-breaking work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go tell Pharaoh (the king of Egypt) to let the Israelites leave his country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses protested to the Lord, “The Israelites wouldn’t listen to me. Why would Pharaoh listen to me? I’m such a poor speaker.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron about the Israelites and Pharaoh (the king of Egypt). He commanded them to bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the heads of the families:
The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
These were the families descended from Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman. These were the families descended from Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the sons of Levi listed in birth order: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Levi lived 137 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon listed by their families were Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi.
These were the families descended from Levi listed in birth order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed. She gave birth to Aaron and Moses. Amram lived 137 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon. She gave birth to Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph.
These were the families descended from Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eleazar, son of Aaron, married one of the daughters of Putiel. She gave birth to Phinehas.
These were the heads of Levite households listed by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the same Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring the Israelites out of Egypt in organized family groups.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They—this same Moses and Aaron—told Pharaoh (the king of Egypt) to let the Israelites leave Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord spoke to Moses in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Moses, “I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh (the king of Egypt) everything I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Why would Pharaoh listen to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered Moses, “I have made you a god to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron is your prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell your brother Aaron everything I command you, and he must tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites leave the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will make Pharaoh stubborn. Even though I will do many miraculous signs and amazing things in Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh will not listen to you. Then I will use my power to punish Egypt severely, and I will bring my people, the Israelites, out of Egypt in organized family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I use my power against Egypt and bring the Israelites out of there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did as the Lord had commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was 80 years old and Aaron was 83 when they talked to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Give me a sign to prove that God has sent you,’ tell Aaron, ‘Take your shepherd’s staff and throw it down in front of Pharaoh,’ and it will become a large snake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did as the Lord had commanded. Aaron threw his staff down in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a large snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh sent for his wise men and sorcerers. These Egyptian magicians did the same thing using their magic spells.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of them threw his staff down, and they all became large snakes. But Aaron’s staff swallowed theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, Pharaoh continued to be stubborn and would not listen to them, as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh is being stubborn. He refuses to let my people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning meet Pharaoh when he’s on his way to the Nile. Wait for him on the bank of the river. Take along the staff that turned into a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to him, ‘The Lord God of the Hebrews sent me to tell you, “Let my people go to worship me in the desert.” So far you have not listened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is what the Lord says: This is the way you will recognize that I am the Lord: With this staff in my hand, I’m going to strike the Nile, and the water will turn into blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fish in the Nile will die, and the river will stink. The Egyptians will not be able to drink any water from the Nile.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—its rivers, canals, ponds, and all its reservoirs—so that they turn into blood. There will be blood everywhere in Egypt, even in the wooden and stone containers.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did as the Lord had commanded. In front of Pharaoh and his officials, Aaron raised his staff and struck the Nile. All the water in the river turned into blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fish in the Nile died, and it smelled so bad that the Egyptians couldn’t drink any water from the river. There was blood everywhere in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Egyptian magicians did the same thing using their magic spells. So Pharaoh continued to be stubborn and would not listen to Moses and Aaron, as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh turned and went back to his palace. He dismissed the entire matter from his mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Egyptians dug along the Nile for water to drink because they couldn’t drink any of the water from the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven days passed after the Lord struck the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord says: Let my people go to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you refuse to let them go, I will bring a plague of frogs on your whole country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nile River will swarm with frogs. They will come into your palace, into your bedroom, on your bed, into the houses of your officials, on your people, into your ovens and into your mixing bowls.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs will jump on you, on your people, and on all your officials.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Hold your staff over the rivers, canals, and ponds. This will bring frogs onto the land.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron held his staff over the waters of Egypt. The frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the magicians did the same thing using their magic spells and brought frogs onto the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron and said, “Pray that the Lord will take the frogs away from me and my people. Then I will let your people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered Pharaoh, “You may have the honor of choosing when I should pray for you, your officials, and your people. Then the frogs will leave you and your homes. The only ones left will be those in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Pray for me tomorrow,” Pharaoh said.
Moses replied, “It will be as you say so that you will know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs will leave you, your homes, your officials, and your people. The only frogs left will be those in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses and Aaron left Pharaoh, Moses prayed to the Lord about the frogs he had brought on Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did what Moses asked. The frogs died in the houses, in the yards, and in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were piled into countless heaps, and the land began to stink because of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh saw that the plague was over, he became stubborn and would not listen to Moses and Aaron, as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Hold out your staff and strike the dust on the ground. All over Egypt the dust will turn into gnats.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses told him, Aaron held out the staff in his hand and struck the dust on the ground. It turned into gnats that bit people and animals. All the dust on the ground everywhere in Egypt turned into gnats.
speaker: Narrator

text: The magicians also tried to produce gnats using their magic spells, but they couldn’t do it. The gnats bit people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the magicians said to Pharaoh, “This is the hand of God!”
Yet, Pharaoh continued to be stubborn and would not listen to Moses and Aaron, as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Early in the morning, stand in Pharaoh’s way when he’s going to the Nile. Say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: Let my people go to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will not let my people go, I will send swarms of flies on you, your officials, your people, and your houses. The homes of the Egyptians will be filled with flies, and even the ground outside will be covered with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on that day I will treat the region of Goshen differently. That is where my people live. There won’t be any flies there. This way you will know that I, the Lord, am here in this land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will distinguish between my people and yours. This miraculous sign will happen tomorrow.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did what he said. Dense swarms of flies came into Pharaoh’s palace and into the houses of his officials. All over Egypt the flies were ruining everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, sacrifice to your God here in this country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses replied, “It wouldn’t be right to do that. The sacrifices we offer to the Lord our God are disgusting to Egyptians. If they see us offer sacrifices that they consider disgusting, won’t they stone us to death?
speaker: Narrator

text: We need to travel three days into the desert to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God, as he told us to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said, “I will let you go, but don’t go very far. You may offer sacrifices to the Lord your God in the desert and pray for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered, “As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the Lord. Tomorrow the swarms of flies will go away from you, your officials, and your people. But you must stop tricking us by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did what Moses asked. The swarms of flies left Pharaoh, his officials, and his people. Not one fly was left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, this time, too, Pharaoh was stubborn and did not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord God of the Hebrews says: Let my people go to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them in slavery,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord will bring a terrible plague on your livestock, including your horses, donkeys, camels, cattle, sheep, and goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord will distinguish between Israel’s livestock and the livestock of the Egyptians. No animals belonging to the Israelites will die.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord set a definite time. He said, “Tomorrow I will do this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the Lord did as he said. All the livestock of the Egyptians died, but none of the Israelites’ animals died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh found out that not one of the Israelites’ animals had died. Yet, Pharaoh continued to be stubborn and would not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Take a handful of ashes from a kiln, and have Moses throw them up in the air as Pharaoh watches.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will become a fine dust throughout Egypt. The dust will cause boils to break into open sores on people and animals throughout Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They took ashes from a kiln and stood in front of Pharaoh. Moses threw the ashes up in the air, and they caused boils to break into open sores on people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The magicians couldn’t compete with Moses because they had boils like all the other Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord made Pharaoh stubborn, so he wouldn’t listen to Moses and Aaron, as the Lord had predicted to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Early in the morning, go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord God of the Hebrews says: Let my people go to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I will send plagues that will affect you personally as well as your officials and people. This is how you will know that there is no one like me anywhere on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: By now I could have used my power to kill you and your people with a plague that would have wiped you off the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have spared you for this reason. I want to show you my power and make my name famous throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are still blocking my people from leaving.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, at this time tomorrow I will send the worst hailstorm that has ever happened in Egypt since the beginning of its history.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, send servants to bring your livestock and everything else you have indoors. All people and animals still outside and not brought in will die when the hail falls on them.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those members of Pharaoh’s court who listened to the Lord’s warning brought their servants and cattle indoors quickly.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who didn’t take the Lord’s warning seriously left their servants and animals out in the open.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Lift your hand toward the sky, and hail will fall on people, animals, and every plant in the fields of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses lifted his staff toward the sky, the Lord sent thunder and hail, and lightning struck the earth. So the Lord made it hail on Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: It hailed, and lightning flashed while it hailed. This was the worst storm in all the land of Egypt since it had become a nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: All over Egypt the hail knocked down everything that was out in the open. It struck down people, animals, and every plant in the fields and destroyed every tree in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: The only place it didn’t hail was the region of Goshen, where the Israelites lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron. “This time I have sinned,” he told them. “The Lord is right, and my people and I are wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray to the Lord. We’ve had enough of God’s thunder and hail. I’ll let you go; you don’t have to stay here any longer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses replied, “As soon as I’m out of the city, I’ll spread out my hands to the Lord in prayer. The thunder will stop, and there will be no more hail. This is how you will know that the earth belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I know that you and your officials still don’t fear the Lord God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (The flax and the barley were ruined, because the barley had formed heads and the flax was in bloom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither the wheat nor the wild grain was damaged, because they ripen later.)
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he left Pharaoh and went out of the city, Moses spread out his hands to the Lord in prayer. The thunder and the hail stopped, and no more rain came pouring down on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh saw that the rain, the hail, and the thunder had stopped, he sinned again. He and his officials continued to be stubborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was stubborn and would not let the Israelites go, as the Lord had predicted through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh. I have made him and his officials stubborn so that I can do these miraculous signs among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be able to tell your children and grandchildren exactly how I treated the Egyptians and what miraculous signs I did among them. This is how you will all know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said to him, “This is what the Lord God of the Hebrews says: How long will you refuse to humble yourself in my presence? Let my people go to worship me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you refuse to let my people go, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your country.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will cover the land so that the ground can’t be seen. They will eat everything left by the hail, including every tree still standing in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will fill your houses and the houses of all your officials and those of all the Egyptians. Your parents and ancestors never saw anything like this from the time they first came here until now.” Moses turned and left Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh’s officials asked him, “How long will this man hold us in his grip? Let the Israelite men go to worship the Lord their God. When will you realize that Egypt is ruined?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh. “Go, worship the Lord your God,” he said to them. “But exactly who will be going?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered, “Everyone! We’ll be taking our young and old, our sons and daughters, our flocks and herds with us. For us it’s a pilgrimage festival in the Lord’s honor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to them, “The Lord would have to be with you if I would ever let you take your women and children along. I know you’re up to no good!
speaker: Narrator

text: No! Only the men may go to worship the Lord, since that’s what you’ve been asking for.” Then Moses and Aaron were thrown out of Pharaoh’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over Egypt to bring locusts. They will invade Egypt and eat up every plant in the land—everything left by the hail.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses held his staff over the land of Egypt, and the Lord made a wind from the east blow over the land all that day and all that night. By morning the east wind had brought the locusts.
speaker: Narrator

text: They invaded all of Egypt and landed all over the country in great swarms. Never before had there been so many locusts like this, nor would there ever be that many again.
speaker: Narrator

text: They covered all the ground until it was black with them. They ate all the plants and all the fruit on the trees that the hail had left. Nothing green was left on any tree or plant anywhere in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh quickly called for Moses and Aaron and said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please forgive my sin one more time. Pray to the Lord your God to take this deadly plague away from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord changed the wind to a very strong west wind. It picked up the locusts and blew them into the Red Sea. Not one locust was left anywhere in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord made Pharaoh stubborn, so he did not let the Israelites go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Lift your hand toward the sky, and a darkness so thick that it can be felt will come over Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses lifted his hand toward the sky, and throughout Egypt there was total darkness for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: People couldn’t see each other, and no one went anywhere for three days. But all the Israelites had light where they were living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and said, “Go, worship the Lord! Even your women and children may go with you, but your flocks and herds must stay behind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “You must allow us to take our animals for the sacrifices and burnt offerings we have to make to the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: All our livestock must go with us. Not one animal must be left behind. We’ll have to use some of them for worshiping the Lord our God, and we won’t know what we’ll need until we get there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord made Pharaoh stubborn, so he refused to let them go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Moses, “Get out of my sight! Don’t ever let me see your face again. The day I do, you will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You’re right!” Moses answered. “You’ll never see my face again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and Egypt. After that he will let you go. When he does, he will be certain to force all of you out of here.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now announce to the people of Israel that each man and woman must ask the Egyptians for silver and gold jewelry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made the Egyptians kind to the people. And Moses was highly respected by Pharaoh’s officials and all the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord says: About midnight I will go out among the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every firstborn son in Egypt will die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who rules the land, to the firstborn children of female slaves who use their handmills, including every firstborn domestic animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be loud crying throughout Egypt, such as there has never been or ever will be again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But where the Israelites are, not even a dog will be startled by any person or animal. This is how you will see that the Lord shows the distinction between Egypt and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all these officials of yours will come, bow down to me, and say, ‘You and all the people who follow you, get out!’ After that I will leave.” Burning with anger, Moses left Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had said to Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you. This is why I will do more amazing things in Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron showed Pharaoh all these amazing things. Yet, the Lord made Pharaoh stubborn, so he wouldn’t let the Israelites leave his country.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron in Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This month will be the very first month of the year for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the whole community of Israel: On the tenth day of this month each man must take a lamb or a young goat for his family—one animal per household.
speaker: Narrator

text: A household may be too small to eat a whole animal. That household and the one next door can share one animal. Choose your animal based on the number of people and what each person can eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your animal must be a one-year-old male that has no defects. You may choose a lamb or a young goat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take care of it until the fourteenth day of this month.
“Then at dusk, all the assembled people from the community of Israel must slaughter their animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must take some of the blood and put it on the sides and tops of the doorframes of the houses where they will eat the animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The meat must be eaten that same night. It must be roasted over a fire and eaten with bitter herbs and unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t eat any of it raw or boiled but roast the whole animal over a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t leave any of it until morning. Anything left over in the morning must be burned up.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you should be dressed when you eat it: with your belt on, your sandals on your feet, and your shepherd’s staff in your hand. You must eat it in a hurry. It is the Lord’s Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On that same night I will go throughout Egypt and kill every firstborn male, both human and animal. I will severely punish all the gods of Egypt, because I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the blood on your houses will be a sign for your protection. When I see the blood, I will pass over you. Nothing will touch or destroy you when I strike Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This day will be one for you to remember. This is a permanent law for generations to come: You will celebrate this day as a pilgrimage festival in the Lord’s honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you must eat unleavened bread. On the very first day you must remove any yeast that you have in your houses. Whoever eats anything with yeast in it from the first day through the seventh day must be excluded from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have a holy assembly on the first day and another one on the seventh. You must not work on these days except to prepare your own meals. That’s all you may do.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread because it was on this very day that I brought you out of Egypt in organized family groups. This is a permanent law for future generations: You must celebrate this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month until the evening of the twenty-first day you must eat unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: There should be no yeast in your houses for seven days. Whoever eats anything with yeast in it must be excluded from the community of Israel, whether he is an Israelite or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat nothing made with yeast. Wherever you live, you must eat only unleavened bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses called for all the leaders of Israel. He said to them, “Pick out a lamb or a young goat for your families, and kill the Passover animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the branch of a hyssop plant, dip it in the blood which is in a bowl, and put some of the blood on the top and sides of the doorframes of your houses. No one may leave the house until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will go throughout Egypt to kill the Egyptians. When he sees the blood on the top and sides of the doorframe, he will pass over that doorway, and he will not let the destroyer come into your home to kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must follow these instructions. They are a permanent law for you and your children.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter the land that the Lord will give you as he promised, observe this ceremony.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your children ask you what this ceremony means to you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you must answer, ‘It’s the Passover sacrifice in the Lord’s honor. The Lord passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt and spared our homes when he killed the Egyptians.’ ”
Then the people knelt, bowing with their faces touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: At midnight the Lord killed every firstborn male in Egypt from the firstborn son of Pharaoh who ruled the land to the firstborn son of the prisoner in jail, and also every firstborn animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh, all his officials, and all the other Egyptians got up during the night. There was loud crying throughout Egypt because in every house someone had died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron during the night. He said, “You and the Israelites must leave my people at once. Go, worship the Lord as you asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your flocks and herds, too, as you asked. Just go! And bless me, too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians begged the people to leave the country quickly. They said, “Soon we’ll all be dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people picked up their bread dough before it had risen and carried it on their shoulders in bowls, wrapped up in their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did what Moses had told them and asked the Egyptians for gold and silver jewelry and for clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made the Egyptians generous to the people, and they gave them what they asked for. So the Israelites stripped Egypt of its wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites left Rameses to go to Succoth. There were about six hundred thousand men on foot, plus all the women and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many other people also went with them, along with large numbers of sheep, goats, and cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the dough they had brought from Egypt, they baked round, flat bread. The dough hadn’t risen because they’d been thrown out of Egypt and had no time to prepare food for the trip.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites had been living in Egypt for 430 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: After exactly 430 years all the Lord’s people left Egypt in organized family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night the Lord kept watch to take them out of Egypt. (All Israelites in future generations must keep watch on this night, since it is dedicated to the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “These are the rules for the Passover:
“No foreigner may eat the Passover meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any male slave you have bought may eat it after you have circumcised him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“No foreigner visiting you may eat it.
“No hired worker may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The meal must be eaten inside one house. Never take any of the meat outside the house.
“Never break any of the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The whole community of Israel must celebrate the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Foreigners may want to celebrate the Lord’s Passover. First, every male in the household must be circumcised. Then they may celebrate the Passover like native-born Israelites. But no uncircumcised males may ever eat the Passover meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same instructions apply to native-born Israelites as well as foreigners.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites did as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day the Lord brought all the Israelites out of Egypt in organized family groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set apart every firstborn male for me. Every firstborn male offspring among the Israelites is mine, whether human or animal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the people, “Remember this day—the day when you left Egypt, the land of slavery. The Lord used his mighty hand to bring you out of there. Don’t eat anything made with yeast.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today, in the month of Abib, you are leaving Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord swore to your ancestors that he would give you the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites, and Jebusites. When he brings you into that land flowing with milk and honey, you must observe this ceremony in this month.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For seven days you must eat unleavened bread. The seventh day will be a pilgrimage festival in the Lord’s honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only unleavened bread should be eaten during these seven days. No sourdough or yeast should be seen anywhere in your territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day tell your children, ‘We do this because of what the Lord did for us when we left Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: This festival will be like a mark on your hand or a reminder on your forehead that the teachings of the Lord are always to be a part of your conversation. Because the Lord used his mighty hand to bring you out of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must follow these rules every year at this time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord brings you to the land of the Canaanites and gives it to you, as he swore to you and your ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: sacrifice every firstborn male offspring to the Lord. The firstborn male offspring of each of your animals belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will cost you a sheep or a goat to buy any firstborn donkey back from the Lord. If you don’t buy it back, then you must break the donkey’s neck. You must also buy every firstborn son back from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the future when your children ask you what this means, tell them, ‘The Lord used his mighty hand to bring us out of slavery in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh was too stubborn to let us go, the Lord killed every firstborn male in Egypt—human and animal. This is why we sacrifice every firstborn male to the Lord and buy every firstborn son back from the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So this festival will be like a mark on your hand and like a band on your forehead, because the Lord used his mighty hand to bring us out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh let the people go, God didn’t lead them on the road through Philistine territory, although that was the shortest route. God said, “If they see that they have to fight a war, they may change their minds and go back to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God led the people around the other way, on the road through the desert toward the Red Sea. The Israelites were ready for battle when they left Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, because Joseph had made the Israelites solemnly swear to do this. Joseph had said, “God will definitely come to help you. When he does, take my bones with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They moved from Succoth and camped at Etham, on the edge of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: By day the Lord went ahead of them in a column of smoke to lead them on their way. By night he went ahead of them in a column of fire to give them light so that they could travel by day or by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The column of smoke was always in front of the people during the day. The column of fire was always there at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites to go back and set up their camp facing Pi Hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea. Set up your camp facing north—by the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh will think, ‘The Israelites are just wandering around. The desert is blocking their escape.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make Pharaoh so stubborn that he will pursue them. Then, because of what I do to Pharaoh and his entire army, I will receive honor, and the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” So that is what the Israelites did.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh (the king of Egypt) was told that the people had fled, he and his officials changed their minds about them. They said, “What have we done? We’ve lost our slaves because we’ve let Israel go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh prepared his chariot and took his army with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took 600 of his best chariots as well as all the other chariots in Egypt, placing an officer in each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made Pharaoh (the king of Egypt) so stubborn that he pursued the Israelites, who were boldly leaving Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians pursued the Israelites. Pharaoh’s army, including all his horse-drawn chariots and cavalry, caught up with them as they were setting up their camp by the sea at Pi Hahiroth facing north.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Pharaoh approached, the Israelites looked up and saw that the Egyptians were coming after them. Terrified, the Israelites cried out to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Moses, “Did you bring us out into the desert to die because there were no graves in Egypt? Look what you’ve done by bringing us out of Egypt!
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t we tell you in Egypt, ‘Leave us alone! Let us go on serving the Egyptians’? It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered the people, “Don’t be afraid! Stand still, and see what the Lord will do to save you today. You will never see these Egyptians again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord is fighting for you! So be still!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelites to start moving.
speaker: Narrator

text: Raise your staff, stretch out your hand over the sea, and divide the water. Then the Israelites will go through the sea on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am making the Egyptians so stubborn that they will follow the Israelites. I will receive honor because of what I will do to Pharaoh, his entire army, his chariots, and cavalry.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I am honored for what I did to Pharaoh, his chariots, and his cavalry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Messenger of God, who had been in front of the Israelites, moved behind them. So the column of smoke moved from in front of the Israelites and stood behind them
speaker: Narrator

text: between the Egyptian camp and the Israelite camp. The column of smoke was there when darkness came, and it lit up the night. Neither side came near the other all night long.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea. All that night the Lord pushed back the sea with a strong east wind and turned the sea into dry ground. The water divided,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Israelites went through the middle of the sea on dry ground. The water stood like a wall on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians pursued them, and all Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, and cavalry followed them into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just before dawn, the Lord looked down from the column of fire and smoke and threw the Egyptian camp into a panic.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the wheels of their chariots come off so that they could hardly move. Then the Egyptians shouted, “Let’s get out of here! The Lord is fighting for Israel! He’s against us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea so that the water will flow back over the Egyptians, their chariots, and their cavalry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses stretched his hand over the sea, and at daybreak the water returned to its usual place. The Egyptians tried to escape, but the Lord swept them into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water flowed back and covered Pharaoh’s entire army, as well as the chariots and the cavalry that had followed Israel into the sea. Not one of them survived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the Israelites had gone through the sea on dry ground while the water stood like a wall on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day the Lord saved Israel from the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians lying dead on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites saw the great power the Lord had used against the Egyptians, they feared the Lord and believed in him and in his servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the Lord:
“I will sing to the Lord.
He has won a glorious victory.
He has thrown horses and their riders into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is my strength and my song.
He is my Savior.
This is my God, and I will praise him,
my father’s God, and I will honor him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is a warrior!
The Lord is his name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has thrown Pharaoh’s chariots and army into the sea.
Pharaoh’s best officers were drowned in the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The deep water covered them.
They sank to the bottom like a rock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your right hand, O Lord, wins glory because it is strong.
Your right hand, O Lord, smashes your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With your unlimited majesty, you destroyed those who attacked you.
You sent out your burning anger.
It burned them up like straw.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With a blast from your nostrils, the water piled up.
The waves stood up like a dam.
The deep water thickened in the middle of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The enemy said, ‘I’ll pursue them!
I’ll catch up with them!
I’ll divide the loot!
I’ll take all I want!
I’ll use my sword!
I’ll take all they have!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your breath blew the sea over them.
They sank like lead in the raging water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is like you among the gods, O Lord?
Who is like you?
You are glorious because of your holiness
and awe-inspiring because of your splendor.
You perform miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You stretched out your right hand.
The earth swallowed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Lovingly, you will lead the people you have saved.
Powerfully, you will guide them to your holy dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will hear of it and tremble.
The people of Philistia will be in anguish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tribal leaders of Edom will be terrified.
The powerful men of Moab will tremble.
The people of Canaan will be deathly afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terror and dread will fall on them.
Because of the power of your arm, they will be petrified
until your people pass by, O Lord,
until the people you purchased pass by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will bring them and plant them on your own mountain,
the place where you live, O Lord,
the holy place that you built with your own hands, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will rule as king forever and ever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh’s horses, chariots, and cavalry went into the sea, the Lord made the water of the sea flow back over them. However, the Israelites had gone through the sea on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet Miriam, Aaron’s sister, took a tambourine in her hand. All the women, dancing with tambourines, followed her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Miriam sang to them:
“Sing to the Lord.
He has won a glorious victory.
He has thrown horses and their riders into the sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses led Israel away from the Red Sea into the desert of Shur. For three days they traveled in the desert without finding water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Marah, they couldn’t drink the water because it tasted bitter. That’s why the place was called Marah [Bitter Place].
speaker: Narrator

text: The people complained about Moses by asking, “What are we supposed to drink?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed  him a piece of wood. He threw it into the water, and the water became sweet.
There the Lord set down laws and rules for them to live by, and there he tested them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If you will listen carefully to the Lord your God and do what he considers right, if you pay attention to his commands and obey all his laws, I will never make you suffer any of the diseases I made the Egyptians suffer, because I am the Lord, who heals you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, they went to Elim, where there were 12 springs and 70 palm trees. They camped there by the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole community of Israelites moved from Elim and came to the desert of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai. This was on the fifteenth day of the second month after they had left Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the desert the whole community complained about Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to them, “If only the Lord had let us die in Egypt! There we sat by our pots of meat and ate all the food we wanted! You brought us out into this desert to let us all starve to death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “I’m going to send you food from heaven like rain. Each day the people should go out and gather only what they need for that day. In this way I will test them to see whether or not they will follow my instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the sixth day when they prepare what they bring home, it should be twice as much as they gather on other days.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the Israelites, “In the evening you will know that it was the Lord who brought you out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning you will see the glory of the Lord, because he has heard you complaining about him. Why are you complaining about us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also said, “The Lord will give you meat to eat in the evening and all the food you want in the morning. The Lord has heard you complaining about him. Who are we? You’re not complaining about us but about the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Tell the whole community of Israelites, ‘Come into the Lord’s presence. He has heard you complaining.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Aaron was speaking to the whole community of Israelites, they looked toward the desert. Suddenly, they saw the glory of the Lord in the column of smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve heard the Israelites complaining. Tell them, ‘At dusk you will eat meat, and in the morning you will eat all the food you want. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: That evening quails came and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the dew was gone, the ground was covered with a thin layer of flakes like frost on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Israelites saw it, they asked each other, “What is this?” because they didn’t know what it was.
Moses said to them, “It’s the food the Lord has given you to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord has commanded: Each of you should gather as much as you can eat. Take two quarts for each person in your tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that is what the Israelites did. Some gathered more, some less.
speaker: Narrator

text: They measured it into two-quart containers. Those who had gathered more didn’t have too much. Those who had gathered less didn’t have too little. They gathered as much as they could eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to them, “No one may keep any of it until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of them didn’t listen to Moses. They kept part of it until morning, and it was full of worms and smelled bad. So Moses was angry with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each morning they gathered as much food as they could eat. When the sun was hot, it melted away.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the sixth day they gathered twice as much food, four quarts per person. All the leaders of the community came to Moses and told him about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “This is what the Lord said: Tomorrow is a day of rest—a holy day dedicated to the Lord. Bake what you want to bake, and boil what you want to boil. Save all that’s left over, and keep it until tomorrow morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they saved it until the next morning as Moses had commanded, but it didn’t smell or have worms in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Eat it today,” Moses said, “because today is a day of rest—a holy day dedicated to the Lord. You won’t find anything on the ground today.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can gather food on six days, but on the seventh day, the day of rest, you won’t find any.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day some people went out to gather food, but they didn’t find any.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will you refuse to do what I have commanded and instructed you to do?
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember: The Lord has given you this day of rest as a holy day. That’s why he gives you enough food on the sixth day for two days. On the seventh day stay in your place—no one is to go out. Everyone, stay where you are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people never worked on the seventh day of the week.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites called the food manna. It was like coriander seeds. It was white and tasted like wafers made with honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: Take two quarts of manna to be kept for your descendants. This way they will see the food that I gave you to eat in the desert when I brought you out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take a jar, put two quarts of manna in it, and put it in the Lord’s presence to be kept for your descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron put the jar of manna in front of the words of God’s promise to be kept there, as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites ate manna for 40 years until they came to a place to settle. They ate manna until they came to the border of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now, the standard dry measure at that time held 20 quarts.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole community of Israelites left the desert of Sin and traveled from place to place as the Lord commanded them. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they complained to Moses by saying, “Give us water to drink!”
Moses said to them, “Why are you complaining to me? Why are you testing the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were thirsty for water there. They complained to Moses and asked, “Why did you bring us out of Egypt? Was it to make us, our children, and our livestock die of thirst?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cried out to the Lord, “What should I do with these people? They’re almost ready to stone me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered Moses, “Bring some of the leaders of Israel with you, and go to where the people can see you. Take the staff you used to strike the Nile River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ll be standing in front of you there by a rock at Mount Horeb. Strike the rock, and water will come out of it for the people to drink.”
Moses did this while the leaders of Israel watched him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He named that place Massah [Testing] and Meribah [Complaining] because the Israelites complained and because they tested the Lord, asking, “Is the Lord with us or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites fought Israel at Rephidim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Joshua, “Choose some of our men. Then fight the Amalekites. Tomorrow I will stand on top of the hill. I will hold in my hand the staff God told me to take along.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua did as Moses told him and fought the Amalekites, while Moses, Aaron, and Hur went to the top of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as Moses held up his hands, Israel would win, but as soon as he put his hands down, the Amalekites would start to win.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Moses’ hands felt heavy. So Aaron and Hur took a rock, put it under him, and he sat on it. Aaron held up one hand, and Hur held up the other. His hands remained steady until sunset.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua defeated the Amalekite army in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Write this reminder on a scroll, and make sure that Joshua hears it, too: I will completely erase any memory of the Amalekites from the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses built an altar and called it The Lord Is My Banner.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Because a hand was lifted against the Lord’s throne, he will be at war against the Amalekites from one generation to the next.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian, heard about everything God had done for Moses and his people Israel and how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had sent away his wife Zipporah, his father-in-law Jethro had taken her in,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with her two sons. The one son was named Gershom [Foreigner], because Moses said, “I was a foreigner living in another country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the other was Eliezer [My God Is a Helper], because he said, “My father’s God was my helper. He saved me from Pharaoh’s death sentence.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law Jethro brought Moses’ sons and wife to Moses in the desert where he was camped near the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro had sent word to Moses, “I’m coming to visit you, and I’m bringing your wife and her two sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went out to meet his father-in-law. Moses bowed with his face touching the ground and kissed Jethro. After they asked each other how they were, they went into the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told his father-in-law everything the Lord had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel, all the hardships they had had on the way, and how the Lord had saved them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro was delighted to hear about all the good things the Lord had done for Israel in rescuing them from the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Thank the Lord! He rescued you from the Egyptians and their Pharaoh and rescued these people from the control of the Egyptians,
speaker: Narrator

text: who treated Israel with contempt. Now I know that the Lord is greater than all other gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and other sacrifices to God. Aaron and all the leaders of Israel came to eat the meal with Moses’ father-in-law in God’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses was settling disagreements among the people. The people stood around Moses from morning until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses’ father-in-law saw everything Moses was doing for the people, he asked, “Why are you doing this for the people? Why do you sit here alone, while all the people stand around you from morning until evening?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered his father-in-law, “Because the people come to me to find out God’s will.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they have a disagreement and bring it to me, I decide which person is right, and I tell them God’s laws and instructions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law replied, “What you’re doing is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and your people will wear yourselves out. This is too much work for you. You can’t do it alone!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen to me, and I’ll give you some advice. May God be with you! You must be the people’s representative to God and bring their disagreements to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must instruct them in the laws and the teachings, show them how to live, and tell them what to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But choose capable men from all the people, men who fear God, men you can trust, men who hate corruption. Put them in charge of groups of 1,000, or 100, or 50, or 10 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them be the ones who usually settle disagreements among the people. They should bring all important cases to you, but they should settle all minor cases themselves. Make it easier for yourself by letting them help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If God commands you, and you do this, you will be able to continue your work, and all these people will have their disagreements settled so that they can go home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses listened to his father-in-law and did everything he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses chose capable men from all the Israelites and put them in charge of groups of 1,000, or 100, or 50, or 10 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men were the ones who usually settled disagreements among the people. They would bring difficult cases to Moses, but they settled all minor ones themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent his father-in-law on his way. So Jethro went back to his own country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two months after the Israelites left Egypt, they came to the desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel had moved from Rephidim and had come into the desert of Sinai. They had set up camp there in front of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went up the mountain to God, and the Lord called to him from the mountain, “This is what you must say to the descendants of Jacob. Tell the Israelites,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have seen for yourselves what I did to Egypt and how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to my mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you carefully obey me and are faithful to the terms of my promise, then out of all the nations you will be my own special possession, even though the whole world is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be my kingdom of priests and my holy nation.’ These are the words you must speak to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down and called for the leaders of the people. He repeated to them all the words that the Lord had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people answered together, “We will do everything the Lord has said.” So Moses brought their answer back to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “I am coming to you in a storm cloud so that the people will hear me speaking with you and will always believe you.” Moses told the Lord what the people had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Moses, “Go to the people, and tell them they have two days to get ready. They must set themselves apart as holy. Have them wash their clothes
speaker: Narrator

text: and be ready by the day after tomorrow. On that day the Lord will come down on Mount Sinai as all the people watch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mark off a boundary around the mountain for the people, and tell them not to go up the mountain or even touch it. Those who touch the mountain must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one should touch them. They must be stoned or shot with arrows. No matter whether it’s an animal or a person, it must not live. The people may go up the mountain only when the ram’s horn sounds a long blast.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses went down the mountain to the people, he had them get ready, and they washed their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the people, “Be ready two days from now. Don’t disqualify yourselves by having sexual intercourse.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the morning of the second day, there was thunder and lightning with a heavy cloud over the mountain, and a very loud blast from a ram’s horn was heard. All the people in the camp shook with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses led the people out of the camp to meet with God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of Mount Sinai was covered with smoke because the Lord had come down on it in fire. Smoke rose from the mountain like the smoke from a kiln, and the whole mountain shook violently.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sound of the horn grew louder and louder, Moses was speaking, and the voice of God answered him.
speaker: Narrator
