text: The Lord came down on top of Mount Sinai and called Moses to the top of the mountain. So Moses went up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go down and warn the people not to force their way through the boundary to see the Lord, or many of them will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the priests who are allowed to come near the Lord must set themselves apart as holy, or the Lord will violently kill them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “The people can’t come up Mount Sinai, because you warned us yourself to mark off a boundary around the mountain and consider it holy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go down, and bring Aaron back with you. But the priests and the people must not force their way through the boundary to come up to the Lord, or he will violently kill them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down to the people and told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God spoke all these words:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of slavery in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never have any other god.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never make your own carved idols or statues that represent any creature in the sky, on the earth, or in the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never worship them or serve them, because I, the Lord your God, am a God who does not tolerate rivals. I punish children for their parents’ sins to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I show mercy to thousands of generations of those who love me and obey my commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never use the name of the Lord your God carelessly. The Lord will make sure that anyone who carelessly uses his name will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember the day of rest by observing it as a holy day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have six days to do all your work.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh day is the day of rest—a holy day dedicated to the Lord your God. You, your sons, your daughters, your male and female slaves, your cattle, and the foreigners living in your city must never do any work on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: In six days the Lord made heaven, earth, and the sea, along with everything in them. He didn’t work on the seventh day. That’s why the Lord blessed the day he stopped his work and set this day apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Honor your father and your mother, so that you may live for a long time in the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never lie when you testify about your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Never desire to take your neighbor’s household away from him.
“Never desire to take your neighbor’s wife, his male or female slave, his ox, his donkey, or anything else that belongs to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people heard the thunder and saw the lightning. They heard the blast of the ram’s horn and saw the mountain covered with smoke. So they shook with fear and stood at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to Moses, “You speak to us, and we’ll listen. But don’t let God speak to us, or we’ll die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses answered the people, “Don’t be afraid! God has come only to test you, so that you will be in awe of him and won’t sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people kept their distance while Moses went closer to the dark cloud where God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “This is what you must say to the Israelites: You’ve seen for yourselves that I have spoken to you from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never make any gods of silver or gold for yourselves. Never worship them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must build an altar for me made out of dirt. Sacrifice your burnt offerings and your fellowship offerings, your sheep, goats, and cattle on it. Wherever I choose to have my name remembered, I will come to you and bless you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you build an altar for me made out of stones, never make it with cut stone blocks. If you use a chisel on it, you will make it unacceptable to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never use stairs to go up to my altar. Otherwise, people will be able to see under your clothes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Here are the legal decisions to be used by the Israelites:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever you buy a Hebrew slave, he will be your slave for six years. In the seventh year he may leave as a free man, without paying for his freedom.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he comes to you by himself, he must leave by himself. If he comes as a married man, his wife may leave with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his master gives him a wife and she gives birth to sons or daughters, the wife and her children belong to the master, and the slave must leave by himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he makes this statement: ‘I hereby declare my love for my master, my wife, and my children. I don’t want to leave as a free man,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then his master must bring him to God. The master must bring him to the door or the doorframe and pierce his ear with an awl. Then he will be his slave for life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever a man sells his daughter into slavery, she will not go free the way male slaves do.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she doesn’t please the master who has chosen her as a wife, he must let her be bought back by one of her close relatives. He has no right to sell her to foreigners, since he has treated her unfairly.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he has chosen her for his son, he must treat her like a daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If that son marries another woman, he must not deprive the first wife of food, clothes, or sex.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he doesn’t give her these three things, she can go free, without paying any money for her freedom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever strikes someone and kills him must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it wasn’t done intentionally, but God let it happen, the killer should flee to a place I will set aside for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whenever someone becomes so angry that he plans to kill his neighbor, you must take him away from my altar and put him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever hits his father or mother must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever kidnaps another person must be put to death, whether he has sold the kidnapped person or still has him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever curses his father or mother must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you must do whenever men quarrel and one hits the other with a rock or with his fist and injures him so that he has to stay in bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the injured man can get up again and walk around outside with a cane, the one who hit him must not be punished. He must pay the injured man for the loss of his time and for all his medical expenses.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever an owner hits his male or female slave with a stick so that the slave dies from the beating, the owner must be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the slave gets up in a day or two, the owner must not be punished. The slave is his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you must do whenever men fight and injure a pregnant woman so that she gives birth prematurely. If there are no other injuries, the offender must pay whatever fine the court allows the woman’s husband to demand.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone is injured, the offender must pay a life for a life,
speaker: Narrator

text: an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, a foot for a foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: a burn for a burn, a bruise for a bruise, a wound for a wound.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever an owner hits his male or female slave in the eye and the slave is blinded, he must let the slave go free to make up for the loss of the eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the owner knocks out the tooth of his male or female slave, he must let the slave go free to make up for the loss of the tooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever a bull gores a man or a woman to death, the bull must be stoned to death, and its meat may not be eaten. The bull’s owner is free from any liability.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the bull has had the habit of goring, and the owner has been warned but has not kept it confined, and it kills a man or a woman, then the bull must be stoned and its owner must be put to death, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if only a cash settlement is demanded from the owner, the bull’s owner may save his life by paying whatever price is demanded of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the bull gores someone’s son or daughter, this same ruling applies.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the bull gores a male or female slave, its owner must pay 12 ounces of silver to the slave’s master, and the bull must be stoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever someone opens up a cistern or digs a new one and doesn’t cover it and a bull or a donkey falls into it,
speaker: Narrator

text: the owner of the cistern must make up for the loss. He must pay money to the animal’s owner, and then the dead animal will be his.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever one person’s bull kills another person’s bull, they must sell the live bull and divide the money between them. They must divide the dead bull, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if it was known that the bull had the habit of goring, and its owner didn’t keep it confined, the owner must make up for the loss—bull for bull—and then the dead bull will be his.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Whenever someone steals a bull or a sheep and butchers it or sells it, he must make up for the loss with five head of cattle to replace the bull or four sheep to replace the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone catches a thief breaking in and hits him so that he dies, he is not guilty of murder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if it happens after sunrise, he is guilty of murder.
“A thief must make up for what he has stolen. If he is unable to do so, he must be sold as a slave to pay for what he stole.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the stolen animal is found alive in his possession, whether it’s a bull, donkey, or a sheep, he must make up for the loss with double the amount.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever someone lets his livestock graze in a field or a vineyard, and they stray and graze in another person’s field, he must make up for what the damaged field was expected to produce. But if he lets them ruin the whole field with their grazing, he must make up from his own field for the loss with the best from his field and vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever a fire starts and spreads into the underbrush so that it burns up stacked or standing grain or ruins a field, the person who started the fire must make up for the loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you must do whenever someone gives his neighbor silver or other valuables to keep for him, and they are stolen from that person’s house: If the thief is caught, he must make up for the loss with double the amount.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the thief is not caught, the owner of the house must be brought to God to find out whether or not he took his neighbor’s valuables.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is a dispute over the ownership of a bull, a donkey, a sheep, an article of clothing, or any other lost property which two people claim as their own, both people must bring their case to God. The one whom God declares guilty must make up for his neighbor’s loss with double the amount.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you must do whenever someone gives his neighbor a donkey, a bull, a sheep, or any other kind of animal to keep for him, and it dies, is injured, or is captured in war, and there are no witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The case between them must be settled by swearing an oath to the Lord that the neighbor did not take the other person’s animal. The owner must accept the oath. The neighbor doesn’t have to make up for the loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the animal was stolen from the neighbor, he must make up for the owner’s loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it was killed by a wild animal, he must bring in the dead body as evidence. He doesn’t have to make up for an animal that has been killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever someone borrows an animal from his neighbor, and it is injured or dies while the owner is not present, the borrower must make up for the loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the owner is with the animal, the borrower doesn’t have to make up for the loss. If it is rented, the rental fee covers the loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever a man seduces a virgin who is not engaged to anyone and has sexual intercourse with her, he must pay the bride-price and marry her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If her father absolutely refuses to give her to him, he must pay an amount of money equal to the bride-price for virgins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never let a witch live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever has sexual intercourse with an animal must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever sacrifices to any god except the Lord must be condemned and destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never mistreat or oppress foreigners, because you were foreigners living in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never take advantage of any widow or orphan.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do and they cry out to me, you can be sure that I will hear their cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will become angry and have you killed in combat. Then your wives and children will become widows and orphans.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you lend money to my people—to any poor person among you—never act like a moneylender. Charge no interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you take any of your neighbor’s clothes as collateral, give it back to him by sunset.
speaker: Narrator

text: It may be the only clothes he has to cover his body. What else will he sleep in? When he cries out to me, I will listen because I am compassionate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never show disrespect for God or curse a leader of your people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Never withhold your best wine from me.
“You must give me your firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must do the same with your cattle and your sheep. They will stay with their mothers seven days, but on the eighth day you must give them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must be my holy people. Never eat the meat of an animal that has been killed by wild animals out in the countryside. Throw it to the dogs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Never spread false rumors. Don’t join forces with wicked people by giving false testimony.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never follow a crowd in doing wrong. When you testify in court, don’t side with the majority to pervert justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never give special favors to poor people in court.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever you come across your enemy’s ox or donkey wandering loose, be sure to take it back to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever you see that the donkey of someone who hates you has collapsed under its load, don’t leave it there. Be sure to help him with his animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never deny justice to poor people in court.
speaker: Narrator

text: Avoid telling lies. Don’t kill innocent or honest people, because I will never declare guilty people innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never take a bribe, because bribes blind those who can see and deny justice to those who are in the right.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never oppress foreigners. You know what it’s like to be foreigners because you were foreigners living in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For six years you may plant crops in your fields and harvest them,
speaker: Narrator

text: but in the seventh year you must leave the land unplowed and unused. In that way the poor among your people will have food to eat, and wild animals may eat what the poor people leave. You must do the same with your vineyards and olive groves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For six days you will do your work, but on the seventh day you must not work. Then your ox and donkey can rest. The slaves born in your household and foreigners will also be refreshed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Be careful to do everything I told you.
“Never mention the names of other gods or let them be heard on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Three times a year you must celebrate a pilgrimage festival in my honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread: For seven days you must eat unleavened bread, as I commanded you. Do this at the appointed time in the month of Abib, because that was when you left Egypt. No one may come into my presence without an offering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Celebrate the Festival of the Harvest with the first produce harvested from whatever you plant in your fields.
“Celebrate the Festival of the Final Harvest at the end of the year when you harvest your crops from the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the three times each year that all your men must come into the presence of the Master, the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never offer the blood of a sacrifice to me at the same time you offer anything containing yeast. The fat sacrificed at my festivals should never be left over in the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You must bring the best of the first produce harvested from your soil to the house of the Lord your God.
“Never cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m going to send a Messenger in front of you to protect you on your trip and bring you to the place I have prepared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay attention to him, and listen to him. Don’t defy him, because he will not forgive your disobedience. He is acting on my authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will listen to him and do everything I say, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and an opponent to your opponents.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My Messenger will go ahead of you and will bring you to the land of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hivites, and Jebusites. I will wipe them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never worship or serve their gods or follow their practices. Instead, you must destroy their gods and crush their sacred stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must serve the Lord your God, and he will bless your food and water. I will take away all sickness from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: No woman in your land will miscarry or be unable to have children. I will let you live a normal life span.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will send my terror ahead of you and throw any nation you meet into a panic. I will make all your enemies flee from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will spread panic ahead of you to force the Hivites, Canaanites, and Hittites out of your way.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not force them out of your way in one year. Otherwise, the land would be deserted, and wild animals would take over.
speaker: Narrator

text: Little by little I will force them out of your way until you have increased enough in number to take possession of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will establish your borders from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean Sea and from the Sinai Desert to the Euphrates River. I will put the people living in the land under your control, and you will force them out of your way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never make a treaty with them and their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never let them live in your land, or they will make you sin against me and trap you into serving their gods.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “You and Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and 70 of Israel’s leaders come up the mountain to me and worship at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses may come near the Lord, but the others may not. The people must not come along with Moses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went and told the people all the Lord’s words and legal decisions. Then all the people answered with one voice, “We will do everything the Lord has told us to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Moses wrote down all the Lord’s words.
Early the next morning he built an altar at the foot of the mountain and set up 12 sacred stones for the 12 tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent young Israelite men, and they sacrificed bulls as burnt offerings and fellowship offerings to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took half of the blood and put it into bowls, and he threw the other half against the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the Book of the Lord’s Promise  and read it while the people listened. They said, “We will obey and do everything the Lord has said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the blood and sprinkled it on the people and said, “Here is the blood which seals the promise that the Lord has made to you based on everything you have just heard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went up with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and 70 of Israel’s leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: They saw the God of Israel. Under his feet was something like a pavement made out of sapphire as clear and blue as the sky itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: God didn’t harm these leaders of the Israelites. So they saw God, and then they ate and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Come up to me on the mountain. Stay there, and I will give you the stone tablets with the teachings and the commandments I have written for the people’s instruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses set out with his assistant Joshua, and Moses went up on the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the leaders, “Wait here for us until we come back to you. Aaron and Hur are here with you. Take all your disagreements to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went up on the mountain, and the cloud covered it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The glory of the Lord settled on Mount Sinai. For six days the cloud covered it, and on the seventh day the Lord called to Moses from inside the cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Israelites, the glory of the Lord looked like a raging fire on top of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses entered the cloud as he went up the mountain. He stayed on the mountain 40 days and 40 nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites to choose something to give me as a special contribution. You must accept whatever contribution each person freely gives.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the kind of contribution you will accept from them: gold, silver, and bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: violet, purple, and bright red yarn, fine linen, goats’ hair,
speaker: Narrator

text: rams’ skins dyed red, fine leather, acacia wood,
speaker: Narrator

text: olive oil for the lamps, spices for the anointing oil and for the sweet-smelling incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: onyx stones, and other precious stones to be set in the chief priest’s ephod  and his breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then have them make a holy place for me, and I will live among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the tent and all its furnishings exactly like the plans I am showing you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make an ark of acacia wood 45 inches long, 27 inches wide, and 27 inches high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cover it with pure gold inside and out, and put a gold molding around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cast four gold rings for it, and fasten them to its four feet, two rings on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make poles of acacia wood, and cover them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the poles through the rings on the sides of the ark in order to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles must stay in the rings of the ark. Never remove them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will put into the ark the words of my promise which I will give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a throne of mercy to cover the ark out of pure gold 45 inches long and 27 inches wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make two angels  out of hammered gold for the two ends of the throne of mercy,
speaker: Narrator

text: one on each end. Form the angels and the throne of mercy out of one piece of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angels should have their wings spread above the throne of mercy, overshadowing it. They should face each other, looking at the throne of mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you put into the ark the words of my promise which I will give you, place the throne of mercy on top.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be above the throne of mercy between the angels whenever I meet with you and give you all my commands for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a table of acacia wood 36 inches long, 18 inches wide, and 27 inches high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cover it with pure gold, and put a gold molding around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a rim three inches wide around it, and put a gold molding around the rim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make four gold rings for it, and fasten them to the four corners, where the four legs are.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rings are to be close to the rim. They are to hold the poles for carrying the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the poles out of acacia wood, cover them with gold, and use them to carry the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make plates and dishes for the table out of pure gold, as well as pitchers and bowls to be used for pouring wine offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the bread of the presence on this table so that it will be in front of me all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a lamp stand out of pure gold. The lamp stand, its base, and its shaft, as well as the flower cups, buds, and petals must be hammered out of one piece of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six branches are to come out of the sides, three branches on one side and three on the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the six branches coming out of the lamp stand is to have three flower cups shaped like almond blossoms, with buds and petals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lamp stand itself is to have four flower cups shaped like almond blossoms, with buds and petals.
speaker: Narrator

text: There should be a bud under each of the three pairs of branches coming out of the lamp stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The buds and branches should also be hammered out of the same piece of pure gold as the lamp stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make seven lamps, and set them on the lamp stand so that they light up the area in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tongs and incense burners must be made of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Use 75 pounds of pure gold to make the lamp stand and all the utensils.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be sure to make them according to the plans you were shown on the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Make the inner tent with ten sheets made from fine linen yarn. Take violet, purple, and bright red yarn, and creatively work an angel  design into the fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each sheet will be 42 feet long and 6 feet wide—all the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of the sheets must be sewn together, and the other five must also be sewn together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make 50 violet loops along the edge of the end sheet in each set,
speaker: Narrator

text: placing the loops opposite each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make 50 gold fasteners. Use them to link the two sets of sheets together so that the tent is a single unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make 11 sheets of goats’ hair to form an outer tent over the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the 11 sheets will be 45 feet long and 6 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sew five of the sheets together into one set and the remaining six into another set. Fold the sixth sheet in half to hang in front of the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make 50 loops along the edge of the end sheet in each set.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make 50 bronze fasteners, and put them through the loops to link the inner tent together as a single unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remaining half-sheet should hang over the back of the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be 18 inches left over on each side because of the length of the outer tent’s sheets. That part should hang over each side in order to cover the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a cover of rams’ skins that have been dyed red for the outer tent. Over that put a cover made of fine leather.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a framework out of acacia wood for the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each frame is to be 15 feet long and 27 inches wide,
speaker: Narrator

text: with two identical pegs. Make all the frames for the inner tent the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make 20 frames for the south side of the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then make 40 silver sockets at the bottom of the 20 frames, two sockets at the bottom of each frame for the two pegs.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the north side of the inner tent make 20 frames
speaker: Narrator

text: and 40 silver sockets, two at the bottom of each frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make six frames for the far end, the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make two frames for each of the corners at the far end of the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: These will be held together at the bottom and held tightly at the top by a single ring. Both corner frames will be made this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be eight frames with 16 silver sockets, two at the bottom of each frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make crossbars out of acacia wood: five for the frames on one side of the inner tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: five for those on the other side, and five for the frames on the far end of the inner tent, the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The middle crossbar will run from one end to the other, halfway up the frames.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cover the frames with gold, make gold rings to hold the crossbars, and cover the crossbars with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set up the inner tent according to the plans you were shown on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a canopy of violet, purple, and bright red yarn. Creatively work an angel design into fine linen yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Use gold hooks to hang it on four posts of acacia wood covered with gold, standing in four silver sockets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hang the canopy from the fasteners in the ceiling, and put the ark containing the words of my promise under it. The canopy will mark off the most holy place from the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the throne of mercy that is on the ark in the most holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Place the table outside the canopy on the north side of the inner tent, and put the lamp stand opposite the table on the south side.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For the entrance of the outer tent, make a screen out of fine linen yarn, embroidered with violet, purple, and bright red yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make five posts of acacia wood for the screen and cover them with gold. Make gold hooks for this screen. Cast five bronze bases for the posts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Make an altar out of acacia wood. It should be 7½ feet square, and 4½ feet high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a horn at each of its four corners. The four horns and the altar must be made out of one piece of wood covered with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make all the utensils for it out of bronze: pots for taking away the altar’s ashes, also shovels, bowls, forks, and incense burners.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a grate for it out of bronze mesh, and make a bronze ring for each of the four corners of the grate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the grate under the ledge of the altar so that it comes halfway up the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make poles out of acacia wood for the altar, and cover them with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles should be put through the rings on both sides of the altar to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make the altar out of boards so that it’s hollow inside. It must be made just as you were shown on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a courtyard for the tent. The south side of the courtyard should be 150 feet long and have curtains made out of fine linen yarn,
speaker: Narrator

text: hung on 20 posts set in 20 bronze bases. The hooks and bands on the posts should be made of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The north side should be the same: 150 feet long, with curtains on 20 posts set in 20 bronze bases. The hooks and bands on the posts should be made of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The courtyard on the west end should be 75 feet wide and have curtains hung on ten posts set in ten bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east end, facing the rising sun, the courtyard should also be 75 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: -Each side of the entrance will be 22½ feet wide with curtains hung on three posts set in three bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The entrance to the courtyard must have a 30-foot screen made from fine linen yarn, embroidered with violet, purple, and bright red yarn, hung on four posts set in four bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the posts around the courtyard should have silver bands, silver hooks, and bronze bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: The courtyard should be 150 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 7½ feet high, with curtains made of fine linen yarn and with bronze bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All the things for the tent, no matter how they’re used, including all the pegs for the tent and the courtyard, must be made of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For the lighting, you must command the Israelites to bring you pure, virgin olive oil so that the lamps won’t go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the tent of meeting outside the canopy where the words of my promise are, Aaron and his descendants must keep the lamps lit in the Lord’s presence from evening until morning. This is a permanent law among the Israelites for generations to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Out of all the Israelites, bring your brother Aaron and his sons Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar to you. They will serve me as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make holy clothes for your brother Aaron to give him dignity and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell all those who have the skill—those to whom I have given this ability—to make Aaron’s clothes. These clothes will set him apart as holy when he serves me as priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the clothes they will make: a breastplate, an ephod and the robe that is worn with it, another specially woven linen robe, the chief priest’s turban, and a cloth belt. They will make these holy clothes for your brother Aaron and his sons so that they can serve me as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must use gold, violet, purple, and bright red yarn, and fine linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make the ephod out of fine linen yarn. Creatively work gold, violet, purple, and bright red yarn into the fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will have two shoulder straps attached at the top corners so that it can be fastened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the belt that is attached to the ephod out of the same fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take two onyx stones, and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel
speaker: Narrator

text: in birth order—six of their names on one stone and the remaining six on the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Engrave the names of the sons of Israel on the two stones the same way a jeweler engraves a signet ring. Mount them in gold settings,
speaker: Narrator

text: and fasten them on the shoulder straps of the ephod as reminders of who the Israelites are. In this way Aaron will carry their names on his shoulders as a reminder in the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make gold settings
speaker: Narrator

text: and two chains of pure gold, twisted like ropes, and fasten these chains to the settings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make the breastplate for decision-making as creatively as you make the ephod. Make it out of gold, violet, purple, and bright red yarn and out of fine linen yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fold it in half so that it’s 9 inches square.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fasten four rows of precious stones on it. In the first row put red quartz, topaz, and emerald.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second row put turquoise, sapphire, and crystal.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third row put jacinth, agate, and amethyst.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth row put beryl, onyx, and gray quartz. Mount them in gold settings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stones correspond to the 12 sons of Israel, by name, each stone engraved (like a signet ring) with the name of one of the 12 tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For the breastplate make chains out of pure gold, twisted like ropes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make two gold rings for the breastplate. Attach them to the two top corners of the breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fasten the two gold ropes to the rings at the top corners of the breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fasten the other ends of the ropes to the two settings on the shoulder straps of the ephod so that the breastplate hangs in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make two gold rings, and fasten them to the other two corners of the breastplate on the inside edge next to the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make two more gold rings, and fasten them to the bottom of the shoulder straps on the front of the ephod. This will be close to the seam just above the belt of the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the breastplate should be fastened by its rings to the rings of the ephod with a violet cord. This will attach it just above the belt of the ephod and will hold the breastplate in place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whenever Aaron goes into the holy place, he will be carrying the names of the sons of Israel over his heart as a constant reminder in the Lord’s presence. He must do this by wearing the breastplate for decision-making.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the Urim and Thummim  into the breastplate for decision-making. They, too, will be over Aaron’s heart when he comes into the Lord’s presence. In this way whenever he’s in the Lord’s presence, Aaron will always be carrying over his heart the means for determining the Lord’s decisions for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make the robe that is worn with the ephod entirely of violet material.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make an opening for the head in the center with a reinforced edge (like a leather collar) all around it to keep it from tearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: All around the hem of the robe make pomegranates of violet, purple, and bright red yarn with gold bells in between—
speaker: Narrator

text: a gold bell alternating with a pomegranate all around the hem of the robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron must wear it when he serves as priest. The sound of the bells must be heard when he comes into and goes out of the Lord’s presence in the holy place so that he won’t die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a flower-shaped medallion out of pure gold, and engrave on it (as on a signet ring): Holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fasten a violet cord to it, and tie it so that it’s on the front of the turban.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be on Aaron’s forehead. He’s the one to be blamed for anything done wrong when the Israelites bring their holy offerings—whatever their gifts may be. The medallion must always be on Aaron’s forehead so that the Lord will accept their offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make the specially woven inner robe of fine linen. Make the turban of fine linen, but the belt should be embroidered with colored yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also make linen robes, belts, and turbans for Aaron’s sons. These clothes will give them dignity and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put these clothes on your brother Aaron and his sons, anoint them, ordain them, and set them apart to serve me as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make linen undergarments to cover them down to their thighs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Aaron and his sons must wear them when they go into the tent of meeting or when they come near the altar to serve as priests in the holy place. Then they will be blameless and won’t die.
“This is a permanent law for him and his descendants.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord continued, “Now, this is what you must do in order to set Aaron and his sons apart to serve me as priests:
“Take a young bull that has no defects and two rams that have no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Use the finest wheat flour, but no yeast, and bake some loaves of bread, some rings of bread made with olive oil, and some wafers brushed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the bread in a basket, and bring the basket along with the young bull and the two rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the tent of meeting, and wash them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the clothes, and put them on Aaron—the linen robe, the ephod and the robe that is worn with it, and the breastplate. Use the belt to tie it on him tightly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put his turban on him, and fasten the holy crown to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the anointing oil, pour it on his head, and anoint him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have his sons come forward. Dress them in their linen robes,
speaker: Narrator

text: and put turbans on them. Tie belts around the waists of Aaron and his sons. They alone are to be priests; this is a permanent law. In this way you will ordain Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then bring the young bull to the front of the tent of meeting. Aaron and his sons will place their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Slaughter the bull in the Lord’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take some of the bull’s blood, and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger. Pour the rest of it out at the bottom of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then take all the fat that covers the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys with the fat on them, and burn them on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But burn the bull’s meat, skin, and excrement outside the camp. It is an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take one of the rams. Then Aaron and his sons will place their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Slaughter it, take the blood, and throw it against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cut the ram into pieces, wash the internal organs and legs, and put them with the other pieces and the head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then burn the whole ram on the altar. It’s a burnt offering, a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the other ram. Then Aaron and his sons will place their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Slaughter it, take some of the blood, and put it on the right ear lobes of Aaron and his sons, on their right thumbs, and on the big toes of their right feet. Throw the rest of the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take some of the blood that is on the altar and some of the anointing oil, and sprinkle it on Aaron and his clothes and on his sons and their clothes. In this way Aaron, his sons, and their clothes will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “From this same ram take the fat, the fat from the tail, the fat that covers the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys with the fat on them, and the right thigh. (This is the ram for the ordination.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the basket of unleavened bread which is in the Lord’s presence, take a round loaf of bread, a ring of bread made with olive oil, and a wafer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put all of these in the hands of Aaron and his sons, who will offer them to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take them from their hands, and burn them on the altar on top of the burnt offering. It’s a soothing aroma in the Lord’s presence, an offering by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the breast from the ram used for Aaron’s ordination, and present it to the Lord. This will be your share.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set apart as holy the breast that is offered to the Lord and the thigh that is the contribution. Both will come from the ram used for the ordination. They both belong to Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a permanent law that the Israelites give this portion to Aaron and his sons as a contribution. This will also be their contribution to the Lord from the fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron’s holy clothes will belong to his descendants so that they can be anointed and ordained in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son who succeeds him as priest—the one who goes into the tent of meeting to serve in the holy place—will wear them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the ram used for the ordination, and boil its meat in a holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the entrance to the tent of meeting, Aaron and his sons will eat the meat of the ram and the bread left in the basket.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will eat those offerings through which they made peace with the Lord at their ordination and installation. No one else may eat them because the offerings are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any meat or bread from the ordination is left over until morning, burn it up. It must not be eaten because it is holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do this with Aaron and his sons exactly as I have commanded you. Take seven days to ordain them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each day sacrifice a young bull as an offering to make peace with the Lord. Sacrifice this offering for sin on the altar in order to pay for its sins. Then anoint it with olive oil in order to dedicate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days at the altar make peace with the Lord and set the altar apart for its holy purpose. Then the altar will be most holy. Anything that touches the altar will become holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what you are to offer on the altar regularly every day: two one-year-old lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer one in the morning and the other at dusk.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the first lamb make an offering of eight cups of flour mixed with one quart of virgin olive oil. Make a wine offering of one quart of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer the other lamb at dusk, and with it make the same grain offering and wine offering as in the morning. This is a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For generations to come this will be the daily burnt offering made in the Lord’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting. There I will meet with you to speak to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will also meet with the Israelites there, and my glory will make this place holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will dedicate the tent of meeting and the altar for their holy purposes. I will set Aaron and his sons apart for their holy duties of serving me as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I will live among the Israelites and be their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will know that I am the Lord their God. I brought them out of Egypt so that I might live among them. I am the Lord their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Build an altar out of acacia wood for burning incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make it 18 inches square and 36 inches high. The horns and altar must be made out of one piece of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cover all of it with pure gold—the top, the sides, and the horns. Put a gold molding around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make two gold rings, and put them below the molding on opposite sides to hold the poles for carrying it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the poles out of acacia wood, and cover them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the altar in front of the canopy which hangs over the ark containing the words of my promise. I will meet with you there in front of the throne of mercy that is on the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron must burn sweet-smelling incense on this altar every morning when he takes care of the lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, when Aaron lights the lamps at dusk, he must burn incense. For generations to come an incense offering must burn constantly in the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never burn any unauthorized incense on this altar or any burnt offerings or grain offerings. Never pour a wine offering on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once a year Aaron must make peace with the Lord by putting blood on its horns. Once a year—for generations to come—blood from the offering must be placed on the altar to make peace with the Lord. It is most holy to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you take a census of the Israelites, each person must pay the Lord a ransom for his life when he is counted. Then no plague will happen to them when they are counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: As each person is counted, he must give one-fifth of an ounce of silver using the standard weight of the holy place. This one-fifth of an ounce of silver is a contribution to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone counted who is at least 20 years old must give this contribution to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich must not give more than one-fifth of an ounce of silver, and the poor must not give less. This contribution is given to make peace with the Lord and make your lives acceptable to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the money the Israelites give to make peace with the Lord, and use it to pay the expenses of the tent of meeting. It will be a reminder for the Israelites in the Lord’s presence that the sins in their lives are removed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make a bronze basin with a bronze stand for washing. Put it between the tent of meeting and the altar, and fill it with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his sons will use it for washing their hands and feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before they go into the tent of meeting, they must wash so that they will not die. Before they come near the altar to serve as priests and burn an offering by fire to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: they will wash their hands and feet so that they will not die. This will be a permanent law for him and his descendants for generations to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the finest spices: 12½ pounds of powdered  myrrh; half as much, that is, 6¼ pounds of fragrant cinnamon; 6¼ pounds of fragrant cane;
speaker: Narrator

text: 12½ pounds of cassia—all weighed using the standard weight of the holy place—and 4 quarts of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have a perfumer make these into a holy oil, a fragrant mixture, used only for anointing. This will be the holy oil used for anointing.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Use it to anoint the tent of meeting, the ark containing the words of my promise,
speaker: Narrator

text: the table and all the dishes, the lamp stand and all the utensils, the altar for incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: the altar for burnt offerings and all its accessories, and the basin with its stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way you will dedicate them for their holy purpose. Then they will be most holy, and anything that touches them will become holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anoint Aaron and his sons as well. In this way you will set them apart for their holy duties of serving me as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the Israelites, ‘For generations to come, this will be my holy oil used only for anointing.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must never be poured on the bodies of other people. Never make any perfumed oil using this formula. It is holy, and you must treat it as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever prepares a perfume like this or puts it on anyone who is not a priest must be excluded from the people.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take one part fragrant spices (two kinds of gum resin and aromatic mollusk shells), and mix them with one part pure frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have a perfumer make it into fragrant incense, seasoned with salt, pure and holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grind some of it into a fine powder, and put it in front of the ark containing the words of my promise in the tent of meeting, where I will meet with you. You must treat it as most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never make any incense for yourselves using this formula. Treat it as holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever prepares anything like it for his own enjoyment must be excluded from his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have chosen Bezalel, son of Uri and grandson of Hur, from the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have filled Bezalel with the Spirit of God, making him highly skilled, resourceful, and knowledgeable in all trades.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’s a master artist familiar with gold, silver, and bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He knows how to cut and set stones and how to work with wood. He’s an expert in all trades.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, I have appointed Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, from the tribe of Dan, to help him. I have given every craftsman the skill necessary to make everything I have commanded you:
speaker: Narrator

text: the tent of meeting, the ark containing the words of my promise with the throne of mercy on it, and all the other furnishings for the tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: the table and the dishes, the pure gold lamp stand and all its utensils, the altar for incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: the altar for burnt offerings and all its accessories, the basin with its stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: the special clothes—the holy clothes for the priest Aaron and the clothes for his sons when they serve as priests,
speaker: Narrator

text: the anointing oil, and the sweet-smelling incense for the holy place. They will make all these things as I commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the Israelites, ‘Be sure to observe my days of rest as holy days. This will be a sign between me and you for generations to come so that you will know that I am the Lord who makes you holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Observe the day of rest because it is holy to you. Whoever treats it like any other day must be put to death. Whoever works on that day must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may work for six days, but the seventh day is a day of rest—a holy day, a day when you don’t work. It is holy to the Lord. Whoever works on that day must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites must observe this day of rest as a holy day, celebrating it for generations to come as a permanent reminder of my promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a permanent sign between me and the Israelites, because the Lord made heaven and earth in six days, and on the seventh day he stopped working and was refreshed.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord finished speaking to Moses on Mount Sinai. Then he gave him the two tablets with his words on them, stone tablets inscribed by God himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people saw that Moses delayed coming down from the mountain, they gathered around Aaron. They said to him, “We don’t know what has happened to this Moses, who led us out of Egypt. Make gods who will lead us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron said to them, “Have your wives, sons, and daughters take off the gold earrings they are wearing, and bring them to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people took off their gold earrings and handed them to Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After he had worked on the gold with a tool, he made it into a statue of a calf.
Then they said, “Israel, here are your gods who brought you out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aaron saw this, he built an altar in front of it and announced, “Tomorrow there will be a festival in the Lord’s honor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next day the people sacrificed burnt offerings and brought fellowship offerings. Afterward, they sat down to a feast, which turned into an orgy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go back down there. Your people whom you brought out of Egypt have ruined everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: They’ve already turned from the way I commanded them to live. They’ve made a statue of a calf for themselves. They’ve bowed down to it and offered sacrifices to it. They’ve said, ‘Israel, here are your gods who brought you out of Egypt.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord added, “I’ve seen these people, and they are impossible to deal with.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now leave me alone. I’m so angry with them I am going to destroy them. Then I’ll make you into a great nation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses pleaded with the Lord his God. “Lord,” he said, “why are you so angry with your people whom you brought out of Egypt using your great power and mighty hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let the Egyptians say, ‘He was planning all along to kill them in the mountains and wipe them off the face of the earth. That’s why he brought them out of our land.’ Don’t be so angry. Reconsider your decision to bring this disaster on your people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Israel. You took an oath, swearing on yourself. You told them, ‘I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky. I will give to your descendants all the land I spoke of. It will be their permanent possession.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord reconsidered his threat to destroy his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses turned and went down the mountain carrying the two tablets with God’s words. They were written on both sides, front and back.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tablets were the work of God, and the writing was God’s writing inscribed on the tablets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua heard the noise of the people shouting. He said to Moses, “It’s the sound of war in the camp!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses replied,
“It’s not the sound of winners shouting.
It’s not the sound of losers crying.
It’s the sound of a wild celebration that I hear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came near the camp, he saw the calf and the dancing. In a burst of anger Moses threw down the tablets and smashed them at the foot of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took the calf they had made, burned it, ground it into powder, scattered it on the water, and made the Israelites drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses asked Aaron, “What did these people do to you that you encouraged them to commit such a serious sin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t be angry, sir,” Aaron answered. “You know that these people are evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to me, ‘We don’t know what’s happened to this Moses who brought us out of Egypt. Make gods for us. They will lead us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I told them to take off any gold they were wearing. They gave it to me. I threw it into the fire, and out came this calf!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron had let the people get out of control, and they became an object of ridicule to their enemies. When Moses saw this,
speaker: Narrator

text: he stood at the entrance to the camp and said, “If you’re on the Lord’s side, come over here to me!” Then all the Levites gathered around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Each of you put on your sword. Go back and forth from one end of the camp to the other, and kill your relatives, friends, and neighbors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites did what Moses told them, and that day about 3,000 people died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “Today you are ordained as the Lord’s priests. God gave you a blessing today because each of you fought with your own sons and brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses said to the people, “You have committed a serious sin. Now I will go up the mountain to the Lord. Maybe I will be able to make a payment for your sin and make peace with the Lord for your sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went back to the Lord and said, “These people have committed such a serious sin! They made gods out of gold for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But will you forgive their sin? If not, please wipe me out of the book you have written.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered Moses, “I will wipe out of my book whoever sins against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, go! Lead the people to the place I told you about. My Messenger will go ahead of you. But when I punish, I will punish them for their sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord killed people because they had Aaron make the calf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “You and the people you brought out of Egypt must leave this place. Go to the land I promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob with an oath, saying, ‘I will give it to your descendants.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send a Messenger ahead of you, and I will force out the Canaanites, Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to that land flowing with milk and honey. But I will not be with you, because you are impossible to deal with, and I would destroy you on the way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people heard this bad news, they acted as if someone had died. No one wore any jewelry.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had said to Moses, “Tell the Israelites, ‘You are impossible to deal with. If I were with you, I might destroy you at any time. Now take off your jewelry, and I’ll decide what to do with you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: After they left Mount Horeb, the Israelites no longer wore their jewelry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Moses used to take a tent and set it up far outside the camp. He called it the tent of meeting. Anyone who was seeking the Lord’s will used to go outside the camp to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever Moses went out to the tent, all the people would rise and stand at the entrances to their tents and watch Moses until he went in.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Moses went into the tent, the column of smoke would come down and stay at the entrance to the tent while the Lord spoke with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people saw the column of smoke standing at the entrance to the tent, they would all bow with their faces touching the ground at the entrance to their own tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord would speak to Moses personally, as a man speaks to his friend. Then Moses would come back to the camp, but his assistant, Joshua, son of Nun, stayed inside the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “You’ve been telling me to lead these people, but you haven’t let me know whom you’re sending with me. You’ve also said, ‘I know you by name, and I’m pleased with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If you really are pleased with me, show me your ways so that I can know you and so that you will continue to be pleased with me. Remember: This nation is your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered, “My presence will go with you, and I will give you peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to him, “If your presence is not going with us, don’t make us leave this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: How will anyone ever know you’re pleased with your people and me unless you go with us? Then we will be different from all other people on the face of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered Moses, “I will do what you have asked, because I am pleased with you, and I know you by name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “Please let me see your glory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “I will let all my goodness pass in front of you, and there I will call out my name ‘the Lord.’ I will be kind to anyone I want to. I will be merciful to anyone I want to.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you can’t see my face, because no one may see me and live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Look, there’s a place near me. Stand by this rocky cliff.
speaker: Narrator

text: When my glory passes by, I will put you in a crevice in the cliff and cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will take my hand away, and you’ll see my back, but my face must not be seen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Cut two more stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on them the words that were on the first tablets which you smashed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be ready in the morning. Then come up on Mount Sinai, and stand in my presence on the top of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one may come with you or even be seen anywhere on the mountain. Even the flocks and herds may not graze in front of this mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cut two more stone tablets like the first ones. Early the next morning he went up on Mount Sinai, as the Lord had commanded him, carrying the two stone tablets.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord came down in a cloud and stood there with him and called out his name “the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he passed in front of Moses, calling out, “The Lord, the Lord, a compassionate and merciful God, patient, always faithful and ready to forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: He continues to show his love to thousands of generations, forgiving wrongdoing, disobedience, and sin. He never lets the guilty go unpunished, punishing children and grandchildren for their parents’ sins to the third and fourth generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately, Moses knelt, bowing with his face touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Lord, please go with us! Even though we are impossible to deal with, forgive our sin and the wrong we have done, and accept us as your own people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “I’m making my promise  again. In front of all your people I will perform miracles that have never been done in any other nation in all the world. All the people around you will see how awesome these miracles are that I will perform for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do everything that I command today. Then I will force the Amorites, Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites out of your way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to make a treaty with those who live in the land where you’re going. This will prove to be a trap to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But tear down their altars, crush their sacred stones, and cut down their poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Never worship any other god, because the Lord is a God who does not tolerate rivals. In fact, he is known for not tolerating rivals.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to make a treaty with those who live in that land. When they chase after their gods as though they were prostitutes and sacrifice to them, they may invite you to eat the meat from their sacrifices with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then your sons will end up marrying their daughters. When their daughters chase after their gods as though they were prostitutes, they’ll lead your sons to do the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never make an idol.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread. As I commanded you, you must eat unleavened bread for seven days at the appointed time in the month of Abib, because in that month you came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every first male offspring is mine, even the firstborn males of all your livestock, whether cattle, sheep, or goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will cost you a sheep or a goat to buy back the firstborn donkey. If you don’t buy it back, then you must break the donkey’s neck. You must buy back every firstborn of your sons.
“No one may come into my presence without an offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may work six days, but on the seventh day you must not work. Even during the time of plowing or harvesting you must not work on this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must celebrate the Festival of Weeks with the first grain from your wheat harvest, and the Festival of the Final Harvest at the end of the season.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Three times a year all your men must come into the presence of the Master, the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will force nations out of your way and will expand your country’s borders. No one will want to take away your land while you’re gone three times a year to the Lord’s festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never offer the blood of a sacrifice to me at the same time you offer anything containing yeast. No part of the sacrifice at the Passover Festival should be left over in the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You must bring the first and best of the produce harvested from your soil to the house of the Lord your God.
“Never cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Write down these words, because on the basis of these words I’m making a promise to Israel and to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was there with the Lord 40 days and 40 nights without food or water. He wrote on the tablets the words of the promise, the ten commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses came down from Mount Sinai, carrying the two tablets with God’s words on them. His face was shining from speaking with the Lord, but he didn’t know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aaron and all the Israelites looked at Moses and saw his face shining, they were afraid to come near him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called to them, so Aaron and all the leaders of the community came back to him. Then Moses spoke to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, all the other Israelites came near him, and he commanded them to do everything the Lord told him on Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses finished speaking to them, he put a veil over his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whenever Moses went into the Lord’s presence to speak with him, he took off the veil until he came out. Whenever he came out and told the Israelites what he had been commanded,
speaker: Narrator

text: they would see that Moses’ face was shining. Then Moses would put the veil back on until he went in again to speak with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses assembled the whole Israelite community and said to them, “These are the things the Lord has commanded you to do:
speaker: Narrator

text: You may work for six days, but the seventh day is a holy day of rest, a day when you don’t work. It is dedicated to the Lord. Whoever does any work on this day should be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never light a fire in any of your homes on this day of rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the whole Israelite community, “This is what the Lord has commanded:
speaker: Narrator

text: Choose something of your own to give as a special contribution to the Lord. Let everyone who is willing bring this kind of contribution to the Lord: gold, silver, and bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: violet, purple, and bright red yarn, fine linen, goats’ hair,
speaker: Narrator

text: rams’ skins dyed red, fine leather, acacia wood,
speaker: Narrator

text: olive oil for the lamps, spices for the anointing oil and for the sweet-smelling incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: onyx stones, and other precious stones to be set in the chief priest’s ephod  and breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have all the skilled craftsmen among you come and make everything the Lord has commanded:
speaker: Narrator

text: the inner tent, the outer tent, and cover, along with the fasteners, frames, crossbars, posts, and sockets,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ark with its poles, the throne of mercy and the canopy over it,
speaker: Narrator

text: the table with its poles, all the dishes, the bread of the presence,
speaker: Narrator

text: the lamp stand used for the light with its utensils, its lamps and the olive oil for the lamps,
speaker: Narrator

text: the altar for incense with its poles, the anointing oil, the sweet-smelling incense, the screen for the entrance to the tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: the altar for burnt offerings with its bronze grate, its poles, and all its accessories, the basin with its stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains for the courtyard, the posts, bases, and the screen for the entrance to the courtyard,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pegs for the tent and the courtyard with their ropes,
speaker: Narrator

text: the special clothes worn for official duties in the holy place—both the holy clothes for Aaron the priest and the clothes for his sons when they serve as priests.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the whole Israelite community left Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were willing and whose hearts moved them came and brought their contributions to the Lord. The gifts were used to construct the tent of meeting, to pay other expenses, and to make the holy clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who were willing—men and women alike—came and brought all kinds of gold jewelry: pins, earrings, signet rings, and pendants. They took these gifts of gold and offered them to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who had violet, purple, or bright red yarn, fine linen, goats’ hair, rams’ skins dyed red, or fine leather brought them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who could give silver or bronze brought it as their contribution to the Lord. Those who had acacia wood that could be used in the construction brought it.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the women who were skilled in spinning yarn brought violet, purple, and bright red yarn, and fine linen, which they had made by hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the women who were willing and had the skill spun the goats’ hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders brought onyx stones and other precious stones to be set in the chief priest’s ephod and breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also brought the spices and the olive oil for the lamps, the anointing oil, and the sweet-smelling incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every Israelite man and woman who was willing brought all these items to the Lord as a freewill offering. They brought these items to be used to make everything the Lord had commanded through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the Israelites, “The Lord has chosen Bezalel, son of Uri and grandson of Hur, from the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has filled Bezalel with the Spirit of God, making him highly skilled, resourceful, and knowledgeable in all trades.
speaker: Narrator

text: He’s a master artist familiar with gold, silver, and bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He knows how to cut and set stones and how to work with wood. He’s an expert in all trades.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, the Lord has given Bezalel and Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, from the tribe of Dan the ability to teach others.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has made these men highly skilled in all trades. They can do the work of jewelers, carpenters, and designers. They know how to embroider violet, purple and bright red yarn on fine linen. They know how to weave yarn on a loom. They can do all kinds of trades. They are master artists.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses continued, “So Bezalel and Oholiab will do the work as the Lord has commanded. They will do this with the help of every other craftsman to whom the Lord has given the necessary skills and talents. They will know how to do all the work for constructing the holy place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called Bezalel and Oholiab and every other craftsman to whom the Lord had given these skills and who was willing to come and do the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses turned over to them all the contributions the Israelites had brought for the work of constructing the holy place. But the people still kept bringing him freewill offerings every morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, all the skilled craftsmen who were working on the holy place stopped what they were doing. They all came to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “The people are bringing much more than we need for doing the work the Lord commanded us to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses gave instructions to have the following message announced all over camp: “No man or woman needs to make anything more to give as their special contribution to the holy place.” Then the people stopped bringing gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: The material they had was more than enough to do the job.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the skilled craftsmen among the workers made the inner tent with ten sheets made from fine linen yarn and violet, purple, and bright red yarn. An angel  design was creatively worked into the fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each sheet was 42 feet long and 6 feet wide—all the same size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of the sheets were sewn together, and the other five were also sewn together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they made 50 violet loops along the edge of the end sheet in each set,
speaker: Narrator

text: placing the loops opposite each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also made 50 gold fasteners. They used them to link the two sets of sheets together so that the inner tent was a single unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made 11 sheets of goats’ hair to form an outer tent over the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the 11 sheets was 45 feet long and 6 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of the sheets were sewn together into one set, and the remaining six into another set.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they made 50 loops along the edge of the end sheet in each set.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also made 50 bronze fasteners to link the inner tent together as a single unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made a cover out of rams’ skins that had been dyed red for the outer tent, and over that they put a cover made of fine leather.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made a framework out of acacia wood for the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each frame was 15 feet long and 27 inches wide,
speaker: Narrator

text: with two identical pegs. They made all the frames for the inner tent this same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made 20 frames for the south side of the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they made 40 silver sockets at the bottom of the 20 frames, two sockets at the bottom of each frame for the two pegs.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the north side of the inner tent they made 20 frames
speaker: Narrator

text: and 40 silver sockets, two at the bottom of each frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made six frames for the far end, the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made two frames for each of the corners at the far end of the inner tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were held together at the bottom and held tightly at the top by a single ring. Both corner frames were made this way.
speaker: Narrator
