text: There were eight frames with 16 silver sockets, two at the bottom of each frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also made crossbars out of acacia wood. Five were for the frames on one side of the inner tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: five were for those on the other side, and five were for the frames on the far side of the inner tent, the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the middle crossbar so that it ran from one end to the other, halfway up the frames.
speaker: Narrator

text: They covered the frames with gold and made gold rings to hold the crossbars. They also covered the crossbars with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the canopy out of violet, purple, and bright red yarn and fine linen yarn. An angel design was creatively worked into the fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made four posts of acacia wood for it and covered them with gold. They made gold hooks for the posts, and they cast four silver bases for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made a screen out of fine linen yarn for the entrance to the outer tent. It was embroidered with violet, purple, and bright red yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also made five posts with hooks for hanging the screen. They covered the tops of the posts and the bands with gold, but the five bases for the posts were made of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bezalel made the ark out of acacia wood 45 inches long, 27 inches wide, and 27 inches high.
speaker: Narrator

text: He covered it with pure gold inside and out and put a gold molding around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cast four gold rings for its four feet, two rings on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made poles out of acacia wood and covered them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put them through the rings on the sides of the ark in order to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the throne of mercy out of pure gold 45 inches long and 27 inches wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made two angels  out of hammered gold for the two ends of the throne of mercy,
speaker: Narrator

text: one on each end. He formed the angels and the throne of mercy out of one piece of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angels had their wings spread above the throne of mercy, overshadowing it. They faced each other, looking at the throne of mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the table out of acacia wood 36 inches long, 18 inches wide, and 27 inches high.
speaker: Narrator

text: He covered it with pure gold and put a gold molding around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a rim 3 inches wide around it and put a gold molding around the rim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cast four gold rings for it and fastened the rings to the four corners, where the four legs were.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rings were put close to the rim to hold the poles for carrying the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: These poles were made out of acacia wood and were covered with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the table he made plates, dishes, bowls, and pitchers to be used for pouring wine offerings. All of them were made out of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the lamp stand out of pure gold. The lamp stand, its base, and its shaft, as well as the flower cups, buds, and petals were hammered out of one piece of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six branches came out of its sides, three branches on one side and three on the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of the six branches coming out of the lamp stand had three flower cups shaped like almond blossoms, with buds and petals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lamp stand itself had four flower cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with a bud and petals.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a bud under each of the three pairs of branches coming out of the lamp stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The buds and branches were hammered out of the same piece of pure gold as the lamp stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the seven lamps, the tongs, and the incense burners out of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lamp stand and all the utensils were made out of 75 pounds of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made an altar out of acacia wood for burning incense. It was 18 inches square and 36 inches high. The horns and altar were made out of one piece of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He covered all of it with pure gold—the top, the sides, and the horns—and he put a gold molding around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made two gold rings and put them below the molding on opposite sides to hold the poles for carrying it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the poles out of acacia wood and covered them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had a perfumer make the holy oil to be used for anointing and for the pure, sweet-smelling incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the altar for burnt offerings out of acacia wood 7½ feet square and 4½ feet high.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a horn at each of its four corners. He made the four horns and the altar out of one piece of wood covered with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made all the utensils out of bronze: pots, shovels, bowls, forks, and incense burners.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a grate for the altar out of bronze mesh, and put it under the ledge, halfway up the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cast four rings to hold the poles (one for each of the four corners of the bronze grate).
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the poles out of acacia wood and covered them with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the poles through the rings on the sides of the altar to carry it. He made the altar out of boards so that it was hollow inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the basin and stand out of the bronze mirrors given by the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made the courtyard. The south side of the courtyard was 150 feet long and had curtains made out of fine linen yarn,
speaker: Narrator

text: hung on 20 posts set in 20 bronze bases. The hooks and bands on the posts were made of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The north side was also 150 feet long with 20 posts and 20 bronze bases. The hooks and bands on the posts were made of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The west side was 75 feet long and had curtains hung on 10 posts set in 10 bases. The hooks and bands on the posts were made of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The east side, facing the rising sun, was 75 feet wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: -Each side of the entrance to the courtyard was 22½ feet wide with curtains hung on three posts set in three bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the curtains around the courtyard were made out of fine linen yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bases for the posts were made of bronze. The hooks and bands on the posts were made of silver. The tops of the posts were covered with silver. And the bands on all the posts of the courtyard were made of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: The screen for the entrance to the courtyard was made of violet, purple, and bright red yarn embroidered on fabric made from fine linen yarn. It was 30 feet long and 7½ feet high, just like the curtains of the courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was hung on four posts set in four bronze bases. The hooks and bands on the posts were made of silver. The tops of the posts were covered with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the pegs for the tent and the surrounding courtyard were made of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the amount of material that was used for the tent (the tent of the words of God’s promise). An inventory was ordered by Moses and carried out by the Levites under the direction of Ithamar, son of the priest Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Bezalel, son of Uri and grandson of Hur, from the tribe of Judah, made everything the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a jeweler, carpenter, designer, and he knew how to embroider violet, purple, and bright red yarn on fine linen. His assistant was Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, from the tribe of Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total amount of gold from the offerings presented to the Lord used in building the holy place weighed over 2,193 pounds, using the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The silver collected when the census of the community was taken weighed 7,544 pounds, using the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: This came to one-fifth of an ounce per person, for everyone counted who was at least 20 years old: 603,550 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He used 7,500 pounds of silver to cast the 100 bases for the holy place and the canopy. This was 75 pounds per base.
speaker: Narrator

text: He used 44 pounds of silver to make the hooks and bands for the posts and the coverings for the tops of the posts.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bronze from the offerings presented to the Lord weighed 5,310 pounds.
speaker: Narrator

text: With this he made the bases for the entrance to the tent of meeting, the bronze altar with its bronze grate and all its accessories,
speaker: Narrator

text: the bases all around the courtyard, the bases for the entrance to the courtyard, all the pegs for the tent, and all the pegs for the surrounding courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the violet, purple, and bright red yarn they made special clothes worn for official duties in the holy place. They also made the holy clothes for Aaron. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the ephod out of fine linen yarn and gold, violet, purple, and bright red yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hammered the gold into thin sheets and cut them up. They twisted the gold into threads, which they creatively worked into each strand of the violet, purple, and bright red yarn, and throughout the fine linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made two shoulder straps attached at the top corners so that the ephod could be fastened.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the belt that is attached to the ephod out of the same fabric. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They mounted the onyx stones in gold settings, and engraved on them the names of the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they fastened them on the shoulder straps of the ephod as a reminder of who the Israelites are. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the breastplate as creatively as they made the ephod. It was made out of gold, violet, purple, and bright red yarn, and of fine linen yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was folded in half and was 9 inches square.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fastened four rows of precious stones on it. In the first row they put red quartz, topaz, and emerald.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second row they put turquoise, sapphire, and crystal.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third row they put jacinth, agate, and amethyst.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth row they put beryl, onyx, and gray quartz. The stones were mounted in gold settings.
speaker: Narrator

text: They corresponded to the 12 sons of Israel, by name, each stone engraved (like a signet ring) with the name of one of the 12 tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the breastplate they made chains out of pure gold, twisted like ropes.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made two gold settings and two gold rings and attached the two rings to the top two corners of the breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fastened the two gold ropes to the rings at the top corners of the breastplate.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fastened the other ends of the ropes to the two settings on the shoulder straps of the ephod so that the breastplate hung in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made two gold rings and fastened them to the other two corners of the breastplate on the inside edge next to the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made two more gold rings and fastened them to the bottom of the shoulder straps on the front of the ephod. This was close to the seam just above the belt of the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they fastened the breastplate by its rings to the rings of the ephod with a violet cord. So the breastplate was attached just above the belt of the ephod and was held in place. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the robe that is worn with the ephod, woven entirely of violet yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: The opening in the center of the robe had a finished edge (like a leather collar) all around it to keep it from tearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the hem of the robe they made pomegranates of violet, purple, and bright red yarn, and fine yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made bells out of pure gold and fastened them in between the pomegranates all around the hem of the robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: A gold bell alternated with a pomegranate all around the hem of the robe that is worn by Aaron when he serves as priest. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They wove inner robes out of fine linen for Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also made the chief priest’s turban and the other beautiful turbans out of fine linen. They made the undergarments and belt out of fine linen yarn.
speaker: Narrator

text: The belt was embroidered with violet, purple, and bright red yarn. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made the flower-shaped medallion (the holy crown) out of pure gold and engraved on it (as on a signet ring): Holy to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fastened a violet cord to it and tied it on top of the turban. They followed the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the work on the inner tent (the tent of meeting) was now done. The Israelites followed all the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they brought everything to Moses—the inner tent, the outer tent and all its furnishings, the fasteners, frames, crossbars, posts, sockets,
speaker: Narrator

text: the cover made of rams’ skins dyed red, the cover made of fine leather, the canopy over the ark,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ark containing the words of God’s promise with its poles and the throne of mercy,
speaker: Narrator

text: the table with all the dishes, the bread of the presence,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pure gold lamp stand with its lamps in a row and all its utensils, the olive oil for the lamps,
speaker: Narrator

text: the gold altar, the anointing oil, the sweet-smelling incense, the screen for the entrance to the tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: the bronze altar with its bronze grate, its poles, and all its accessories, the basin with its stand,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains for the courtyard, the posts, bases, and screen for the entrance to the courtyard, the ropes and pegs—all the equipment needed for the service of the inner tent (the tent of meeting)—
speaker: Narrator

text: the special clothes worn when serving as priests in the holy place—both the holy clothes for the priest Aaron and the clothes for his sons when serving as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites had done all the work following the Lord’s instructions to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses inspected all the work and saw that they had followed the Lord’s instructions. So Moses blessed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set up the tent (the tent of meeting) on the first day of the first month of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place the ark containing the words of my promise inside it, and hang the canopy over the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring in the table, and arrange everything on it. Bring in the lamp stand, and set up the lamps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the gold altar for incense in front of the ark. Put up the screen at the entrance to the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Put the altar for burnt offerings in front of the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put the basin between the tent of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set up the surrounding courtyard, and put up the screen at the entrance to the courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the anointing oil, and anoint the tent and everything in it. In this way you will dedicate it and all its furnishings. Then it will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anoint the altar for burnt offerings and all the utensils. In this way you will dedicate the altar, and it will be most holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anoint the basin and stand, and they will be dedicated.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the tent of meeting, and wash them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then dress Aaron in the holy clothes, and anoint him. In this way you will dedicate him to serve me as priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have his sons come forward, and dress them in their linen robes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anoint them to serve me as priests, as you anointed their father. Their anointing will begin a permanent priesthood for them for generations to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did everything as the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the tent was set up on the first day of the first month of the second year after the Israelites had left Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses set up the tent, he put the sockets in place, put up the frames, inserted the crossbars, and set up the posts.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spread the outer tent over the inner tent and put the cover on top. Moses followed the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the words of God’s promise and put them in the ark. He put the poles on the ark and placed the throne of mercy on top of the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought the ark into the tent and hung the canopy over it to mark off where the ark was. Moses followed the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses put the table in the tent of meeting on the north side of the tent outside the canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He arranged the bread on the table in the Lord’s presence, following the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed the lamp stand in the tent of meeting opposite the table, on the south side of the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up the lamps in the Lord’s presence, following the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses put the gold altar in the tent of meeting in front of the canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned sweet-smelling incense on it, following the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he put up the screen at the entrance to the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the altar for burnt offerings at the entrance to the tent (the tent of meeting). He sacrificed burnt offerings and grain offerings on it. Moses followed the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the basin between the tent of meeting and the altar and put water in it for washing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Aaron, and his sons used this water to wash their hands and feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would wash whenever they went into the tent of meeting or whenever they approached the altar. Moses followed the Lord’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up the courtyard around the tent and the altar and put up the screen at the entrance to the courtyard. Finally, Moses finished the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the column of smoke covered the tent of meeting, and the glory of the Lord filled the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses couldn’t go into the tent of meeting, because the smoke settled on it and the glory of the Lord filled the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all their travels, whenever the column of smoke moved from the tent, the Israelites would break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the column didn’t move, they wouldn’t break camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord’s column stayed over the tent during the day, and there was fire in the smoke at night. In this way all the Israelites could see the column throughout their travels.
speaker: Narrator
